element.label: Lock-in
element.desc: Quick overview and access to all the settings and properties for signal generation and demodulation.

element.label: Lock-in MF
element.desc: Quick overview and access to all the settings and properties for signal generation and demodulation.

element.label: Lock-in MD
element.desc: Quick overview and access to all the settings and properties for signal generation and demodulation.

element.label: Numeric
element.desc: Access to all continuously streamed measurement data as numerical values.

element.label: Plotter
element.desc: Displays various continuously streamed measurement data as traces over time (roll-mode).

element.label: Scope
element.desc: Displays shots of data samples in time and frequency domain (FFT) representation.

element.label: SW Trig
element.desc: Provides complex trigger functionality on all continuously streamed data samples and time domain display.

element.label: Spectrum
element.desc: Provides FFT functionality to all continuously streamed measurement data.

element.label: Sweeper
element.desc: Allows to scan one variable (of a wide choice, e.g. frequency) over a defined range and display various response functions including statistical operations.

element.label: AU
element.desc: Real-time arithmetic operations on demodulator outputs.

element.label: Aux
element.desc: Controls all settings regarding the auxiliary inputs and auxiliary outputs.

element.label: In/Out
element.desc: Access to all controls relevant for the main Signal Inputs and Signal Outputs on the instrument's front.

element.label: DIO
element.desc: Gives access to all controls relevant for the digital inputs and outputs including the Ref/Trigger connectors.

element.label: Config
element.desc: Provides access to software configuration.

element.label: Device
element.desc: Provides instrument specific settings.

element.label: PID
element.desc: Features all control and analysis capabilities of the PID controllers.

element.label: PLL
element.desc: Features all control and analysis capabilities of the phase-locked loops.

element.label: MOD
element.desc: Control panel to enable (de)modulation at linear combinations of oscillator frequencies.

element.label: Boxcar
element.desc: Boxcar settings and periodic waveform analyzer for fast input signals.

element.label: Out PWA
element.desc: Multi-channel boxcar settings and measurement analysis for boxcar outputs.

element.label: Debug
element.desc: Debug settings and controls.

element.label: ZI Labs
element.desc: Experimental settings and controls.

element.label: Files
element.desc: Access files on internal flash memory and USB drive.
Access settings and measurement data files on the host computer.

element.label: HF2CA
element.desc: Remote control of the HF2CA Current Amplifier.

element.label: HF2TA
element.desc: Remote control of the HF2TA Current Amplifier.

element.label: AWG
element.desc: Generate arbitrary signals using sequencing and sample-by-sample definition of waveforms.

element.label: IA
element.desc: Quick overview and access to all the settings and properties for impedance measurements.

element.label: Counter
element.desc: Configure the Pulse Counters for analysis of pulse trains on the digital signal inputs.

element.label: Range
element.desc: Defines the gain of the analog input amplifier. The range should exceed the incoming signal by roughly a factor two including a potential DC offset.
element.descExt: Note 1: the value inserted by the user may be approximated to the nearest value supported by the Instrument. Note 2: a proper choice of range setting is crucial in order to achieve good accuracy and best possible signal to noise ratio as it targets to use the full dynamic range of the input ADC.

element.label: Auto
element.desc: Automatic adjustment of the Range to about two times the maximum signal input amplitude measured over about 100 ms.

element.label: Scaling
element.desc: Applies an arbitrary scale factor to the input signal.

element.label: Measurement Unit
element.desc: Defines the physical unit of the input signal. Use *, / and ^ operators, e.g., m or m/s^2.
element.descExt: The value in this field modifies the readout of all measurement tools in the user interface. Typical uses of this field is to make measurements in the unit before the sensor/transducer, e.g. to take an transimpedance amplifier into account and to directly read results in Ampere instead of Volts.

element.label: AC
element.desc: Defines the input coupling for the Signal Inputs. AC coupling inserts a high-pass filter.

element.label: 50 Ω
element.desc: Switches between 50 Ω (ON) and 1 MΩ (OFF).
Switches between 50 Ω (ON) and 10 MΩ (OFF).

element.label: Float
element.desc: Switches between floating (ON) and connected grounds (OFF). This setting is shared for the voltage and current input.

element.label: Diff
element.desc: Switches between single ended (OFF) and differential (ON) measurements.
Switch input mode between normal (OFF), inverted, and differential. The differential modes are implemented digitally and are not suited for analog common-mode rejection.

element.label: Range
element.desc: Defines the gain of the current input amplifier. The range should exceed the incoming signal by roughly a factor two including a potential DC offset.
element.descExt: Note 1: the value inserted by the user may be approximated to the nearest value supported by the Instrument. Note 2: a proper choice of range setting is crucial in order to achieve good accuracy and best possible signal to noise ratio as it targets to use the full dynamic range of the input ADC.

element.label: Auto
element.desc: Automatic adjustment of the Range to about two times the maximum current input amplitude measured over about 100 ms.

element.label: Scaling
element.desc: Applies an arbitrary scale factor to the current input.

element.label: Measurement Unit
element.desc: Defines the physical unit of the current input. Use *, / and ^ operators, e.g., m or m/s^2
element.descExt: The value in this field modifies the readout of all measurement tools in the user interface.

element.label: Mode
element.desc: Indicates how the frequency of the corresponding oscillator is controlled (manual, external reference). Read only flag.
Indicates how the frequency of the corresponding oscillator is controlled (manual, external reference, PLL, PID). Read only flag.

option.label: Manual
option.desc: The user setting defines the oscillator frequency.

option.label: ExtRef
option.desc: An external reference is mapped onto the oscillator frequency.

option.label: PLL
option.desc: The HF2-PLL option controls the oscillator frequency.

option.label: PLL
option.desc: The UHF-PID option controls the oscillator frequency.

option.label: PID
option.desc: The HF2-PID option controls the oscillator frequency.

option.label: PID
option.desc: The UHF-PID option controls the oscillator frequency.

element.label: Frequency (Hz)
element.desc: Frequency control for each oscillator.

element.label: Locked
element.desc: Oscillator locked to external reference when turned on.

element.label: Mode
element.desc: Indicates the unit that uses the demodulator (Demod stands for regular lock-in amplifier or external reference)
Indicates the unit that uses the demodulator (Demod stands for regular lock-in amplifier, external reference, PLL)

option.label: Demod
option.desc: Default operating mode with demodulator used for lock-in demodulation.

option.label: ExtRef
option.desc: The demodulator is used for external reference mode and tracks the frequency of the selected reference input.

option.label: PLL
option.desc: The demodulator is used in PLL mode for frequency tracking of the signal. Note this function requires the HF2-PLL option to be installed and active on your instrument.

option.label: PLL
option.desc: The demodulator is used in PLL mode for frequency tracking of the signal. Note this function requires the UHF-PID option to be installed and active on your instrument.

option.label: Mod
option.desc: The demodulator is used by the HF2-MOD option, e.g. for the direct demodulation of carrier and sideband signals.

option.label: Mod
option.desc: The demodulator is used by the UHF-MOD option, e.g. for the direct demodulation of carrier and sideband signals.

element.label: Osc
element.desc: Connects the selected oscillator with the demodulator corresponding to this line. Number of available oscillators depends on the installed options.

element.label: Harm
element.desc: Multiplies the demodulator's reference frequency with the integer factor defined by this field.
element.descExt: Multiplies the demodulator's reference frequency by an integer factor. If the demodulator is used as a phase detector in external reference mode (PLL), the effect is that the internal oscillator locks to the external frequency divided by the integer factor.

element.label: Harm
element.desc: Divides the demodulator's reference frequency by an integer factor in external reference mode.
element.descExt: Multiplies the demodulator's reference frequency by an integer factor. If the demodulator is used as a phase detector in external reference mode (PLL), the effect is that the internal oscillator locks to the external frequency divided by the integer factor.

element.label: Demod Freq (Hz)
element.desc: Indicates the frequency used for demodulation and for output generation.
element.descExt: The demodulation frequency is calculated with oscillator frequency times the harmonic factor. When the UHF-MOD option is used linear combinations of oscillator frequencies including the harmonic factors define the demodulation frequencies.

The demodulation frequency is calculated with oscillator frequency times the harmonic factor. When the HF2LI-MOD option is used linear combinations of oscillator frequencies including the harmonic factors define the demodulation frequencies.

The demodulation frequency is calculated with oscillator frequency times the harmonic factor. When the MF-MOD option is used linear combinations of oscillator frequencies including the harmonic factors define the demodulation frequencies.

element.label: Phase (deg)
element.desc: Phase shift applied to the reference input of the demodulator.
element.descExt: When the HF2LI-MF option is used, the phase shift is also applied to the Signal Outputs.

element.label: Zero
element.desc: Adjust the demodulator phase automatically in order to read zero degrees.
element.descExt: Shifts the phase of the reference at the input of the demodulator in order to achieve zero phase at the demodulator output. This action maximizes the X output, zeros the Y output, zeros the Θ output, and leaves the R output unchanged.

element.label: Signal
element.desc: Selects the signal source to be associated to the demodulator.

option.label: Sig In 1
option.desc: Signal Input 1 is connected to the corresponding demodulator.

option.label: Curr In 1
option.desc: Current Input 1 is connected to the corresponding demodulator.

option.label: Sig In 2
option.desc: Signal Input 2 is connected to the corresponding demodulator.

option.label: Trigger 1
option.desc: Trigger 1 is connected to the corresponding demodulator.

option.label: Aux In 1
option.desc: Auxiliary Input 1 is connected to the corresponding demodulator. The input bandwidth is limited to 20 kHz.

option.label: Trigger 2
option.desc: Trigger 2 is connected to the corresponding demodulator.

option.label: Aux In 2
option.desc: Auxiliary Input 2 is connected to the corresponding demodulator. The input bandwidth is limited to 20 kHz.

option.label: Aux Out 1
option.desc: Auxiliary Output 1 is connected to the corresponding demodulator.

option.label: DIO D0
option.desc: DIO D0 is connected to the corresponding demodulator. The input bandwidth is limited to 2 MHz.

option.label: Aux Out 2
option.desc: Auxiliary Output 2 is connected to the corresponding demodulator.

option.label: DIO D1
option.desc: DIO D1 is connected to the corresponding demodulator. The input bandwidth is limited to 2 MHz.

option.label: Aux Out 3
option.desc: Auxiliary Output 3 is connected to the corresponding demodulator.

option.label: Aux Out 4
option.desc: Auxiliary Output 4 is connected to the corresponding demodulator.

option.label: Aux In 1
option.desc: Auxiliary Input 1 is connected to the corresponding demodulator.

option.label: Aux In 2
option.desc: Auxiliary Input 2 is connected to the corresponding demodulator.

option.label: Oscillator Phase Demod 4
option.desc: Oscillator Phase of Demod 4 is connected to the corresponding demodulator.

option.label: Oscillator Phase Demod 8
option.desc: Oscillator Phase of Demod 8 is connected to the corresponding demodulator.

element.label: Order
element.desc: Selects the filter roll off between 6 dB/oct and 48 dB/oct.

option.desc: 1st order filter 6 dB/oct
2nd order filter 12 dB/oct
3rd order filter 18 dB/oct
4th order filter 24 dB/oct
5th order filter 30 dB/oct
6th order filter 36 dB/oct
7th order filter 42 dB/oct
8th order filter 48 dB/oct

element.label: TC/BW Select
element.desc: Defines the display unit of the low-pass filters: time constant (TC) in seconds, noise equivalent power bandwidth (BW NEP) in Hz, 3 dB bandwidth (BW 3 dB) in Hz.

option.label: TC
option.desc: Defines the low-pass filter characteristic using time constant (s) of the filter.

option.label: BW NEP
option.desc: Defines the low-pass filter characteristic using the noise equivalent power bandwidth (Hz) of the filter.

option.label: BW 3 dB
option.desc: Defines the low-pass filter characteristic using the 3 dB cut-off frequency (Hz) of the filter.

element.label: TC/BW Value
element.desc: Defines the low-pass filter characteristic in the unit defined above.

element.label: Sinc
element.desc: Enables the sinc filter.
element.descExt: When the filter bandwidth is comparable to or larger than the demodulation frequency, the demodulator output may contain frequency components at the frequency of demodulation and its higher harmonics. The sinc is an additional filter that attenuates these unwanted components in the demodulator output.

element.label: Lock
element.desc: Makes all demodulators filter settings equal (order, time constant, bandwidth).
element.descExt: Pressing the lock copies the settings from demodulator one into the settings of all demodulators. When the lock is pressed, any modification to a field is immediately changing all other settings. Releasing the lock does not change any setting, and permits to individually adjust the filter settings for each demodulator.

element.label: Enable Streaming
element.desc: Enables the data acquisition for the corresponding demodulator. Note: increasing number of active demodulators increases load on physical connection to the host computer.

option.label: ON: demodulator active
option.desc: Enables the streaming of demodulated samples in real time to the host computer. The streaming rate is defined in the field on the right hand side. As a consequence demodulated samples can be visualized on the plotter and a corresponding numeric entry in the numerical tool is activated.

option.label: OFF: demodulator inactive
option.desc: Disables the streaming of demodulated samples to the host computer.

element.label: Rate (Sa/s)
element.desc: Defines the demodulator sampling rate, the number of samples that are sent to the host computer per second. A rate of about 7-10 higher as compared to the filter bandwidth usually provides sufficient aliasing suppression.
element.descExt: This is also the rate of data received by LabOne Data Server and saved to the computer hard disk. This setting has no impact on the sample rate on the auxiliary outputs connectors. Note: the value inserted by the user may be approximated to the nearest value supported by the instrument.

element.label: Demodulator Output Rate Lock
element.desc: Makes all demodulator output rates equal.
element.descExt: Pressing the lock copies the settings from demodulator one into the settings of all demodulators. When the lock is pressed, any modification to a field is immediately changing all other settings. Releasing the lock does not change any setting, and permits to individually adjust the demodulator output rate for each demodulator.

element.label: Trigger
element.desc: Selects the acquisition mode of demodulated samples. Continuous trigger means data are streamed to the host computer at the Rate indicated.

option.label: Continuous
option.desc: Selects continuous data acquisition mode. The demodulated samples are streamed to the host computer at the Rate indicated on the left hand side. In continuous mode the numerical and plotter tools are continuously receiving and display new values.

option.label: Trigger 1
option.desc: Selects external triggering by means of the Trigger 1 connector. Demodulated samples are sent to the host computer for each event defined in the Trig Mode field. When edge trigger is selected the rate field is greyed out and has no meaning.

option.label: Trigger 3
option.desc: Selects external triggering by means of the Trigger 3 connector. Demodulated samples are sent to the host computer for each event defined in the Trig Mode field. When edge trigger is selected the rate field is greyed out and has no meaning. Note: some UHF Instruments feature Trigger 1/2 on the back panel instead of Trigger 3/4.

option.label: DIO 0
option.desc: Samples are sent to the host computer depending on DIO 0 triggering.

option.label: Trigger 2
option.desc: Selects external triggering by means of the Trigger 2 connector. Demodulated samples are sent to the host computer for each event defined in the Trig Mode field. When edge trigger is selected the rate field is greyed out and has no meaning.

option.label: Trigger 4
option.desc: Selects external triggering by means of the Trigger 4 connector. Demodulated samples are sent to the host computer for each event defined in the Trig Mode field. When edge trigger is selected the rate field is greyed out and has no meaning. Note: some UHF Instruments feature Trigger 1/2 on the back panel instead of Trigger 3/4.

option.label: DIO 1
option.desc: Samples are sent to the host computer depending on DIO 1 triggering.

option.label: Trigger 1|2
option.desc: Same functionality as above, but triggering is based on a logical OR function of Trigger 1 and Trigger 2.

option.label: Trigger 3|4
option.desc: Same functionality as above, but triggering is based on a logical OR function of Trigger 3 and Trigger 4. Note: some UHF Instruments feature Trigger 1/2 on the back panel instead of Trigger 3/4.

option.label: DIO 0|1
option.desc: Samples are sent to the host computer depending on DIO 0 and 1 triggering.

element.label: Trig Mode
element.desc: Defines the edge or level trigger mode for the selected Trigger input. Note: this field only appears when a non-continuous trigger is selected in the Trigger field.

option.label: Rising
option.desc: Selects triggered sample acquisition mode on rising edge of the selected Trigger input.

option.label: Falling
option.desc: Selects triggered sample acquisition mode on falling edge of the selected Trigger input.

option.label: Both
option.desc: Selects triggered sample acquisition mode on both edges of the selected Trigger input.

option.label: High
option.desc: Selects continuous sample acquisition mode on high level of the selected Trigger input. In this selection, the sample rate field determines the frequency in which demodulated samples are sent to the host computer.

option.label: Low
option.desc: Selects continuous sample acquisition mode on low level of the selected Trigger input. In this selection, the sample rate field determines the frequency in which demodulated samples are sent to the host computer.

element.label: Amplitude Unit
element.desc: Select the unit of the displayed amplitude value. The dBm value is only valid for a system with 50 Ω termination.
Select the unit of the displayed amplitude value.

element.label: Amp Enable
element.desc: Enables individual output signal amplitude.
element.descExt: When the MF-MD option is used, it is possible to generate signals being the linear combination of the available demodulator frequencies.
When the UHF-MF option is used, it is possible to generate signals being the linear combination of the available demodulator frequencies.
When the HF2LI-MF option is used, it is possible to generate signals being the linear combination of the available demodulator frequencies.

element.label: On
element.desc: Main switch for the Signal Output corresponding to the blue LED indicator on the instrument front panel.

element.label: 50Ω
element.desc: Select the load impedance between 50Ω and HiZ. The impedance of the output is always 50Ω. For a load impedance of 50Ω the displayed voltage is half the output voltage to reflect the voltage seen at the load.

element.label: Range
element.desc: Defines the maximum output voltage that is generated by the corresponding Signal Output. This includes the potential multiple Signal Amplitudes and Offsets summed up. Select the smallest range possible to optimize signal quality.
element.descExt: This setting ensures that no levels or peaks above the setting are generated, and therefore it limits the values that can be entered as output amplitudes. Therefore selected output amplitudes are clipped to the defined range and the clipping indicator turns on. If 50 Ω target source or differential output is enabled the possible maximal output range will be half.

option.label: 10 mV
option.desc: Selects output range ±10 mV.

option.label: 100 mV
option.desc: Selects output range ±100 mV.

option.label: 1 V
option.desc: Selects output range ±1 V.

option.label: 10 V
option.desc: Selects output range ±10 V.

option.label: 150 mV
option.desc: Selects output range ±150 mV.

option.label: 1.5 V
option.desc: Selects output range ±1.5 V.

element.label: Auto Range
element.desc: Selects the most suited output range automatically.

element.label: Output Clipping
element.desc: Indicates that the specified output amplitude(s) exceeds the range setting. Signal clipping occurs and the output signal quality is degraded. Adjustment of the range or the output amplitudes is required.

element.label: Offset
element.desc: Defines the DC voltage that is added to the dynamic part of the output signal.

element.label: Add
element.desc: The signal supplied to the Aux Input 1 is added to the signal output. For differential output the added signal is a common mode offset.
The signal supplied to the add input is added to the signal output.

element.label: Diff
element.desc: Switch between single-ended output (OFF) and differential output (ON). In differential mode the signal swing is defined between Signal Output +V / -V.

element.label: Output
element.desc: Defines the output amplitude as rms or peak-to-peak value. A negative amplitude value is equivalent to a phase change of 180 degree.

Defines the output amplitude for each demodulator frequency as rms or peak-to-peak value. A negative amplitude value is equivalent to a phase change of 180 degree. Demodulator 7 is the signal source for Signal Output 1, demodulator 8 is the source for Signal Output 2.

Defines the output amplitude for each demodulator frequency as rms or peak-to-peak value. A negative amplitude value is equivalent to a phase change of 180 degree. Demodulator 4 is the signal source for Signal Output 1, demodulator 8 is the source for Signal Output 2.

element.label: Amp (V)
element.desc: Defines the output amplitude for each demodulator frequency as rms or peak-to-peak value.
element.descExt: A negative amplitude value is equivalent to a phase change of 180 degree. Linear combination of multiple amplitude settings on the same output are clipped to the range setting. Note: the value inserted by the user may be approximated to the nearest value supported by the Instrument.

element.label: AWG
element.desc: Indicates that the output amplitude is generated by the AWG.

element.label: Bandwidth Limit
element.desc: Bandwidth of input aliasing filter at 600 MHz (ON) or 900 MHz (OFF) cut off frequency.

element.label: Frequency Source
element.desc: Frequency source

element.label: Sigin Probe
element.desc: Sigin Probe: external probe selection

element.label: Sigin ZCtrl
element.desc: ZCtrl: select probe connector

element.label: Probe Channel
element.desc: Probe Channel: select external probe channel

element.label: Select a Preset
element.desc: Select numerical view based on a preset. Alternatively, the displayed value may also selected based on tree elements.

option.label: Demods Polar
option.desc: Shows R and Phase of all demodulators.

option.label: Enabled Demods Polar
option.desc: Shows R and Phase of enabled demodulators.

option.label: Demods Cartesian
option.desc: Shows X and Y of all demodulators.

option.label: Enabled Demods Cartesian
option.desc: Shows X and Y of enabled demodulators.

option.label: Demods R
option.desc: Shows R of all demodulators.

option.label: Enabled Impedances
option.desc: Shows impedance, model parameters, and frequency.

option.label: Boxcars
option.desc: Shows amplitude of all boxcars.

option.label: PID Errors
option.desc: Shows error of all PID.

option.label: Arithmetic Units
option.desc: Shows output of all Cartesian and polar arithmetic units.

option.label: Unpopulated
option.desc: Shows no signals.

option.label: Manual
option.desc: If additional signals are added or removed the active preset gets manual.

element.label: Name
element.desc: Name of the selected plot(s). The default name can be changed to reflect the measured signal.

element.label: Mapping
element.desc: Mapping of the selected plot(s)

option.label: Lin
option.desc: Enable linear scaling.

option.label: Log
option.desc: Enable logarithmic scaling.

option.label: dB
option.desc: Enable logarithmic scaling in dB.

element.label: Scaling
element.desc: Scaling of the selected plot(s)

element.label: Zoom To Limits
element.desc: Adjust the zoom to the current limits of the displayed histogram data.

element.label: Start Value
element.desc: Start value of the selected plot(s). Only visible for manual scaling.

element.label: Stop Value
element.desc: Stop value of the selected plot(s). Only visible for manual scaling.

element.label: Run/Stop
element.desc: Start and stop continuous data plotting (roll mode)

element.label: Select a Preset
element.desc: Select a pre-defined group signals. A signal group is defined by a common unit and signal type.
element.descExt: They should have the same scaling behavior as they share a y-axis. Split a group if the signals have different scaling properties.

option.label: Enabled Demods R
option.desc: Selects the amplitude of all enabled demodulators.

option.label: Enabled Demods Cartesian
option.desc: Selects X and Y of all enabled demodulators.

option.label: Enabled Demods Polar
option.desc: Selects amplitude and phase of all enabled demodulators.

option.label: Enabled Impedances
option.desc: Shows impedance, model parameters, and frequency.

option.label: Boxcars
option.desc: Selects the amplitude of boxcar 1 and 2.

option.label: PID Errors
option.desc: Selects the error of all PID.

option.label: Arithmetic Units
option.desc: Selects the output of all Cartesian and polar arithmetic units.

option.label: Unpopulated
option.desc: Shows no signals.

option.label: Manual
option.desc: Selects the signals as defined in the tree sub-tab.

element.label: Window Length
element.desc: Plotter memory depth. Values larger than 10 s may cause excessive memory consumption for signals with high sampling rates. Auto scale or pan causes a refresh of the display for which only data within the defined window length are considered.

element.label: Rate
element.desc: Streaming Rate of the scope channels. The streaming rate can be adjusted independent from the scope sampling rate. The maximum rate depends on the interface used for transfer. Note: scope streaming requires the DIG option.

element.label: Enable
element.desc: Enable scope streaming for the specified channel. This allows for continuous recording of scope data on the plotter and streaming to disk. Note: scope streaming requires the DIG option.

element.label: Run/Stop
element.desc: Runs the scope/FFT continuously.

element.label: Single
element.desc: Acquires a single shot of samples.

element.label: Force
element.desc: Force a trigger event.

element.label: Mode
element.desc: Switches between time and frequency domain display.

element.label: Sampling Rate
element.desc: Defines the sampling rate of the scope.

element.label: Signal Input
element.desc: Selects the source for the scope input.

element.label: Length Mode
element.desc: Switches between length and duration display.

option.label: Length (pts)
option.desc: The scope shot length is defined in number of samples. The duration is given by the number of samples divided by the sampling rate. The UHF-DIG option greatly increases the available length.
The scope shot length is defined in number of samples. The duration is given by the number of samples divided by the sampling rate. The MF-DIG option greatly increases the available length.

option.label: Duration (s)
option.desc: The scope shot length is defined as a duration. The number of samples is given by the duration times the sampling rate.

element.label: Length (pts) or Duration (s)
element.desc: Defines the length of the recorded scope shot. Use the Length Mode to switch between length and duration display.

element.label: Channel 1/2
element.desc: Selects the source for scope channel. Navigate through the tree view that appears and click on the required signal. Note: Channel 2 requires the DIG option.

custom.label: Signal Input, Current Input, Trigger Inputs, Auxiliary Inputs, Demodulator Oscillator Phase, Demodulator X/Y/R/Theta
Signal Inputs, Trigger Inputs, Auxiliary Inputs, Demodulator Oscillator Phase, Demodulator X/Y/R/Theta, PID, Boxcar, AU

element.label: Min
element.desc: Lower limit of the scope full scale range. For demodulator, PID, Boxcar, and AU signals the limit should be adjusted so that the signal covers the specified range to achieve optimal resolution.

element.label: Max
element.desc: Upper limit of the scope full scale range. For demodulator, PID, Boxcar, and AU signals the limit should be adjusted so that the signal covers the specified range to achieve optimal resolution.

element.label: Enable
element.desc: Activates the display of the corresponding scope channel. Note: Channel 2 requires the DIG option.

element.label: Avg Filter
element.desc: Selects averaging filter type that is applied when the average of several scope shots is computed and displayed.

option.label: None
option.desc: Averaging is turned off.

option.label: Exponential Moving Avg
option.desc: Consecutive scope shots are averaged with an exponential weight.

element.label: Averages
element.desc: The number of shots required to reach 63% settling. Twice the number of shots yields 86% settling.

element.label: Reset
element.desc: Resets the averaging filter.

element.label: Trigger
element.desc: When flashing, indicates that new scope shots are being captured and displayed in the plot area. The Trigger must not necessarily be enabled for this indicator to flash. A disabled trigger is equivalent to continuous acquisition. Scope shots with data loss are indicated by yellow. Such an invalid scope shot is not processed.

element.label: Enable
element.desc: When triggering is enabled scope data are acquired every time the defined trigger condition is met.

option.label: ON
option.desc: Trigger based scope shot acquisition

option.label: OFF
option.desc: Continuous scope shot acquisition

element.label: Signal
element.desc: Selects the trigger source signal. Navigate through the tree view that appears and click on the required signal.
Selects the trigger source signal.

option.label: Signal Input
Off
Signal Inputs
option.desc: Switches the scope off.

option.label: Current Input
Continuous
Trigger Inputs
option.desc: A new waveform is acquired and displayed after the hold off time. The trigger source is ignored.

option.label: Trigger Inputs
Signal Inputs 1/2
Auxiliary Inputs
option.desc: A new waveform is acquired and displayed when the respective Signal Input is matching the trigger condition.

option.label: Auxiliary Input
Signal Outputs 1/2
Demodulator Oscillator Phase
option.desc: A new waveform is acquired and displayed when the respective Signal Output is matching the trigger condition.

option.label: Demodulator Oscillator Phase
Oscillators 1-8
Demodulator X/Y/R/Theta
option.desc: A new waveform is acquired and displayed when the respective Oscillator is matching the trigger condition.

option.label: Demodulator X/Y/R/Theta
DIO 0/1
PID
option.desc: A new waveform is acquired and displayed when the respective DIO signal is matching the trigger condition.

element.label: Edge Rise
element.desc: Performs a trigger event when the source signal crosses the trigger level from low to high. For dual edge triggering, select also the falling edge.

element.label: Edge Fall
element.desc: Performs a trigger event when the source signal crosses the trigger level from high to low. For dual edge triggering, select also the rising edge.

element.label: Edge
element.desc: Selects which edge of the trigger signal performs a trigger event.

option.label: Falling
option.desc: Performs a trigger event when the source signal crosses the trigger level from high to low.

option.label: Rising
option.desc: Performs a trigger event when the source signal crosses the trigger level from low to high.

element.label: Level (V)
element.desc: Defines the trigger level.

element.label: Level (%)
element.desc: Defines the trigger level relative to signal full scale.

element.label: Hysteresis Mode
element.desc: Selects the mode to define the hysteresis strength. The relative mode will work best over the full input range as long as the analog input signal does not suffer from excessive noise.

option.label: Hysteresis (V)
option.desc: Selects absolute hysteresis.

option.label: Hysteresis (%)
option.desc: Selects a hysteresis relative to the adjusted full scale signal input range.

element.label: Hysteresis (V)
element.desc: Defines the voltage the source signal must deviate from the trigger level before the trigger is rearmed again. Set to 0 to turn it off. The sign is defined by the Edge setting.

element.label: Hysteresis (%)
element.desc: Hysteresis relative to the adjusted full scale signal input range. A hysteresis value larger than 100% is allowed.

element.label: Show Level
element.desc: If enabled shows the trigger level as grey line in the plot. The hysteresis is indicated by a grey box. The trigger level can be adjusted by drag and drop of the grey line.

element.label: Trigger Gating
element.desc: Select the signal source used for trigger gating if gating is enabled. This feature requires the UHF-DIG option.
Select the signal source used for trigger gating if gating is enabled. This feature requires the MF-DIG option.

option.label: Trigger In 1 High
option.desc: Only trigger if the Trigger Input 1 is at high level.

option.label: Trigger In 3 High
option.desc: Only trigger if the Trigger Input 3 is at high level.

option.label: Trigger In 1 Low
option.desc: Only trigger if the Trigger Input 1 is at low level.

option.label: Trigger In 3 Low
option.desc: Only trigger if the Trigger Input 3 is at low level.

option.label: Trigger In 2 High
option.desc: Only trigger if the Trigger Input 2 is at high level.

option.label: Trigger In 4 High
option.desc: Only trigger if the Trigger Input 4 is at high level.

option.label: Trigger In 2 Low
option.desc: Only trigger if the Trigger Input 2 is at low level.

option.label: Trigger In 4 Low
option.desc: Only trigger if the Trigger Input 4 is at low level.

element.label: Trigger Gating Enable
element.desc: If enabled the trigger will be gated by the trigger gating input signal. This feature requires the UHF-DIG option.
If enabled the trigger will be gated by the trigger gating input signal. This feature requires the MF-DIG option.

element.label: Holdoff Mode
element.desc: Selects the holdoff mode.

option.label: Holdoff (s)
option.desc: Holdoff is defined as time.

option.label: Holdoff (events)
option.desc: Holdoff is defined as number of events.

element.label: Holdoff (s)
element.desc: Defines the time before the trigger is rearmed after a recording event.

element.label: Holdoff (events)
element.desc: Defines the trigger event number that will trigger the next recording after a recording event. A value one will start a recording for each trigger event.

element.label: Reference (%)
element.desc: Trigger reference position relative to the plot window. Default is 50% which results in a reference point in the middle of the acquired data.

element.label: Delay (s)
element.desc: Trigger position relative to reference. A positive delay results in less data being acquired before the trigger point, a negative delay results in more data being acquired before the trigger point.

element.label: Enable
element.desc: Enable segmented scope recording. This allows for full bandwidth recording of scope shots with a minimum dead time between individual shots. This functionality requires the DIG option.

element.label: Segments
element.desc: Specifies the number of segments to be recorded in device memory. The maximum scope shot size is given by the available memory divided by the number of segments. This functionality requires the DIG option.

element.label: Shown Segment
element.desc: Displays the number of recorded segments.

element.label: Shown Trigger
element.desc: Displays the number of triggered events since last start.

element.label: FFT Window
element.desc: Four different FFT windows to choose from. Each window function results in a different trade-off between amplitude accuracy and spectral leakage. Please check the literature to find the window function that best suits your needs.

element.label: Resolution (Hz)
element.desc: Spectral resolution defined by the reciprocal acquisition time (sample rate, number of samples recorded).

element.label: Spectral Density
element.desc: Calculate and show the spectral density. If power is enabled the power spectral density value is calculated. The spectral density is used to analyze noise.

element.label: Power
element.desc: Calculate and show the power value. To extract power spectral density (PSD) this button should be enabled together with Spectral Density.

element.label: Persistence
element.desc: Keeps previous scope shots in the display.
element.descExt: The color scheme visualizes the number of occurrences at certain positions in time and amplitude by a multi-color scheme.

element.label: BW Limit Ch 1
element.desc: Selects between sample decimation and sample averaging. Averaging avoids aliasing, but may conceal signal peaks.

option.label: ON
option.desc: Selects sample averaging for sample rates lower than the maximal available sampling rate.

option.label: OFF
option.desc: Selects sample decimation for sample rates lower than the maximal available sampling rate.

element.label: BW Limit Ch 2
element.desc: Selects between sample decimation and sample averaging. Averaging avoids aliasing, but may conceal signal peaks. Channel 2 requires the DIG option.

option.label: ON
option.desc: Selects sample averaging for sample rates lower than the maximal available sampling rate. Channel 2 requires the DIG option.

option.label: OFF
option.desc: Selects sample decimation for sample rates lower than the maximal available sampling rate. Channel 2 requires the DIG option.

element.label: BW Limit
element.desc: Select between scope sample decimation and averaging. Averaging avoids aliasing but may conceal single-sample peaks.

element.label: Run/Stop
element.desc: Start and stop the software trigger

element.label: Single
element.desc: Run the SW trigger once (record Count trigger events)

element.label: Triggered
element.desc: When green, indicates that new trigger shots are being captured and displayed in the plot area.

element.label: Trigger Signal
element.desc: Source signal for trigger condition.

option.label: Demodulator X/Y/R/Theta/Frequency, Auxiliary Inputs, Trigger Inputs, Trigger Outputs, Demodulator 0 Degree Oscillator Phase Crossing

element.label: Trigger Type
element.desc: Select the type of trigger to use. Selectable options depend on the selected trigger signal.

option.label: Edge
option.desc: Analog edge triggering based on high and low level. Hysteresis on the levels and low-pass filtering can be used to reduce the risk of wrong trigger for noisy trigger signals.

option.label: Digital
option.desc: Digital triggering on the 32 bit DIO lines. The bit value defines the trigger conditions. The bit mask controls the bits that are used for trigger evaluation. For triggering just on DIO0 use a bit value 0x0001 and a bit mask 0x0001.

option.label: Pulse
option.desc: Triggers if a pulse on an analog signal is within the min and max pulse width. Pulses can be defined as either low to high then high to low (positive), the reverse (negative) or both.

option.label: Tracking Edge
option.desc: Edge triggering with automatic adjustment of trigger levels to compensate for drifts. The tracking speed is controlled by the bandwidth of the low-pass filter. For this filter noise rejection can only be achieved by level hysteresis.

option.label: HW Trigger
option.desc: Trigger on one of the four trigger inputs. Ensure that the trigger level and the trigger coupling is correctly adjusted. The trigger input state can be monitored on the plotter.

option.label: Tracking Pulse
option.desc: Pulse triggering with automatic adjustment of trigger levels to compensate for drifts. The tracking speed is controlled by the bandwidth of the low-pass filter. For this filter noise rejection can only be achieved by level hysteresis.

option.label: Pulse Count
option.desc: Trigger on trigger events supplied by the pulse counter. This allows for high resolution triggering. The pulse counter must be enabled and configured on the pulse counter tab. This functionality requires the UHF-CNT option.

element.label: Force
element.desc: Forces a single trigger event.

element.label: Pulse Type
element.desc: Select between negative, positive or both pulse forms in the signal to trigger on.

element.label: Trigger Edge
element.desc: Triggers when the trigger input signal is crossing the trigger level from either high to low, low to high or both. This field is only displayed for trigger type Edge, Tracking Edge and Event Count.

element.label: Bits
element.desc: Specify the value of the DIO to trigger on. All specified bits have to be set in order to trigger. This field is only displayed for trigger type Digital.

element.label: Bit Mask
element.desc: Specify a bit mask for the DIO trigger value. The trigger value is bits AND bit mask (bitwise). This field is only displayed for trigger type Digital.

element.label: Level
element.desc: Specify the trigger level value.

element.label: Find
element.desc: Automatically find the trigger level based on the current signal.

element.label: Hysteresis
element.desc: The hysteresis is important to trigger on the correct edge in the presence of noise. The hysteresis is applied below the trigger level for positive trigger edge selection. It is applied above for negative trigger edge selection, and on both sides for triggering on both edges.

element.label: Event Type
element.desc: Type of event to trigger on for pulse counter trigger signals.

option.label: Any
option.desc: Trigger on every sample from the pulse counter, regardless of the counter value.

option.label: Increment
option.desc: Trigger on incrementing counter values.

element.label: Count
element.desc: Number of trigger events to record (in Single mode)

element.label: Trigger progress
element.desc: The percentage of triggers already acquired (in Single mode)

element.label: Bandwidth (Hz)
element.desc: Bandwidth of the low-pass filter applied to the trigger signal. For edge and pulse trigger use a bandwidth larger than the signal sampling rate divided by 20 to keep the phase delay. For tracking filter use a bandwidth smaller than signal sampling frequency divided by 100 to just track slow signal components like drifts.

element.label: Enable
element.desc: Enable low-pass filtering of the trigger signal.

element.label: Hold Off Time
element.desc: Hold off time before the trigger is rearmed. A hold off time smaller than the duration will lead to overlapping trigger frames.

element.label: Hold Off Count
element.desc: Number of skipped triggers until the next trigger is recorded again.

element.label: Delay
element.desc: Time delay of trigger frame position (left side) relative to the trigger edge. For delays smaller than 0, trigger edge inside trigger frame (pre trigger). For delays greater than 0, trigger edge before trigger frame (post trigger)

element.label: Duration
element.desc: Recording length for each triggered data set.

element.label: Pulse Min
element.desc: Minimum pulse width to trigger on.

element.label: Pulse Max
element.desc: Maximum pulse width to trigger on.

element.label: Mode
element.desc: Enable the grid mode for two-dimensional data recording and select horizontal data resampling method.

option.label: Off
option.desc: Grid mode disabled.

option.label: Nearest
option.desc: Grid mode enabled. Resampling is performed using substitution by closest data point.

option.label: Linear
option.desc: Grid mode enabled. Resampling is performed using linear interpolation.

element.label: Operation
element.desc: Select row update method.

option.label: Replace
option.desc: New row replaces old row.

option.label: Average
option.desc: The data for each row is averaged over a number of repetitions.

element.label: Columns
element.desc: Number of columns. The data along the horizontal axis are resampled to a number of samples defined by this setting.

element.label: Rows
element.desc: Number of rows

element.label: Scan Direction
element.desc: Select the scan direction and mode

option.label: Forward
option.desc: Scan direction from left to right

option.label: Reverse
option.desc: Scan direction from right to left

option.label: Bidirectional
option.desc: Alternate scanning in both directions

element.label: Repetitions
element.desc: Number of repetitions used for averaging

element.label: AWG Control
element.desc: If enabled, the row number is identified based on the digital row ID number set by the AWG. If disabled, every new trigger event is attributed to a new row sequentially.

element.label: History
element.desc: Each entry in the list corresponds to a single trigger trace in the history. The number of triggers displayed in the plot is limited to 20. Use the toggle buttons to hide/display individual traces. Use the color picker to change the color of a trace in the plot. Double click on an entry to edit its name.

element.label: Clear All
element.desc: Remove all records from the history list.

element.label: All
element.desc: Select all records from the history list.

element.label: None
element.desc: Deselect all records from the history list.

element.label: Length
element.desc: Maximum number of entries stored in the measurement history. The number of entries displayed in the list is limited to the most recent 100.

element.label: Save
element.desc: Save all trigger event based traces in the history to file.Which data is saved depends on the demodulator channels present in the Vertical Axis Groups of the Control sub-tab

element.label: Run/Stop
element.desc: Run the FFT spectrum analysis continuously

element.label: Single
element.desc: Run the FFT spectrum analysis once

element.label: Demodulator
element.desc: Select the input demodulator for FFT spectrum analysis

element.label: Mode
element.desc: Select the source signal for FFT spectrum analysis. Enable spectral density to extract noise values. In order to extract peak values ensure that spectral density is disabled.

option.label: FFT(X+iY)
option.desc: Complex FFT of the demodulator result (zoom FFT). The center frequency is defined by the oscillator frequency of the demodulator. The span is twice the demodulator sampling rate.

option.label: FFT(R)
option.desc: FFT of the demodulator amplitude result sqrt(x² + y²). The FFT is single sided as performed on real data.

option.label: FFT(Θ)
option.desc: FFT of the demodulator phase result atan2(y, x). The FFT is single sided as performed on real data.

option.label: FFT(f)
option.desc: FFT of the oscillator frequency of the selected demodulator. This mode is only interesting if the oscillator is controlled by a PID/PLL controller. The FFT is single sided as performed on real data.

option.label: FFT(dΘ/dt)/(2π)
option.desc: FFT of the demodulator phase derivative. This value is equivalent to the frequency noise observed on the demodulated signal. The FFT is single sided as performed on real data.

element.label: Power
element.desc: Calculate and show the power value. To extract power spectral density (PSD) this button should be enabled together with spectral density.

element.label: Spectral Density
element.desc: Calculate and show the spectral density. If power is enabled the power spectral density value is calculated. The spectral density is used to analyze noise.

element.label: Sample Rate (Hz)
element.desc: Equivalent to sampling rate of demodulator. The resulting frequency span is equal to the sample rate. Increase the sample rate to reduce aliasing.

element.label: Auto
element.desc: Automatic adjustment of the sampling rate. The rate will be selected to achieve good enough anti-aliasing for the selected demodulator bandwidth.

element.label: Center Freq (Hz)
element.desc: Demodulation frequency of the selected demodulator used as input for the spectrum. For complex FFT(X+iY) the demodulation frequency defines the center frequency of the displayed FFT.

element.label: Aliasing Reject (dB)
element.desc: Resulting aliasing rejection based on demodulator sampling rate and low-pass filter settings. If the value is too low either increase the sampling rate or lower the filter bandwidth.

element.label: Length (pts)
element.desc: Number of lines of the FFT spectrum. A higher value increases the frequency resolution of the spectrum.

element.label: Sampling Progress
element.desc: The percentage of the FFT buffer already acquired.

element.label: Window
element.desc: Four different FFT windows to choose from. Depending on the application it makes a huge difference which of the provided window function is used. Please check the literature to find out the best trade off for your needs.

element.label: Avg Filter
element.desc: Selects the type of averaging.

element.label: Averages
element.desc: Defines the number of spectra which are averaged and displayed.

element.label: Reset
element.desc: Press once to reset the averaging filter.

element.label: Resolution (Hz)
element.desc: Spectral resolution defined by the reciprocal acquisition time (sample rate, number of samples recorded).

element.label: Overlap
element.desc: Overlap of demodulator data used for the FFT transform. Use 0 for no overlap and 0.99 for maximal overlap.

element.label: Filter Compensation
element.desc: Spectrum is corrected by demodulator filter transfer function. Allows for quantitative comparison of amplitudes of different parts of the spectrum.

element.label: Absolute Frequency
element.desc: Shifts x-axis labeling to show the demodulation frequency in the center as opposed to 0 Hz, when turned off.

element.label: Run/Stop
element.desc: Runs the sweeper continuously.

element.label: Single
element.desc: Runs the sweeper once.

element.label: Copy From Range
element.desc: Takes over start and stop value from the plot area.

element.label: Start (unit)
element.desc: Start value of the sweep parameter. The unit adapts according to the selected sweep parameter.

element.label: Stop (unit)
element.desc: Stop value of the sweep parameter. The unit adapts according to the selected sweep parameter.

element.label: Length
element.desc: Sets the number of measurement points.

element.label: Progress
element.desc: Reports the sweep progress as ratio of points recorded.

element.label: Sweep Param.
element.desc: Selects the parameter to be swept. Navigate through the tree view that appears and click on the required parameter. Note: the available selection depends on the configuration of the device.

element.label: Sweep Mode
element.desc: Select the scanning type, default is sequential (incremental scanning from start to stop value)

option.label: Sequential
option.desc: Sequential sweep from Start to Stop value

option.label: Binary
option.desc: Non-sequential sweep continues increase of resolution over entire range

option.label: Bidirectional
option.desc: Sequential sweep from Start to Stop value and back to Start again

option.label: Reverse
option.desc: Reverse sweep from Stop to Start value

element.label: Log
element.desc: Selects between linear and logarithmic distribution of the sweep parameter.

element.label: Remaining
element.desc: Reporting of the remaining time of the current sweep. A valid number is only displayed once the sweeper has been started. An undefined sweep time is indicated as NaN.

element.label: Dual Plot
element.desc: Toggle between single plot view and dual plot view

element.label: Filter
element.desc: Application Mode: automatic mode. Advanced Mode: manual configuration.

option.label: Application Mode
option.desc: The sweeper sets the filters and other parameters automatically.

option.label: Advanced Mode
option.desc: The sweeper uses manually configured parameters.

element.label: Application
element.desc: Select the sweep application mode

option.label: Parameter Sweep
option.desc: Only one data sample is acquired per sweeper point.

option.label: Parameter Sweep Averaged
option.desc: Multiple data samples are acquired per sweeper point of which the average value is displayed.

option.label: Noise Amplitude Sweep
option.desc: Multiple data samples are acquired per sweeper point of which the standard deviation is displayed (e.g. to determine input noise).

option.label: Freq Response Analyzer
option.desc: Narrow band frequency response analysis. Averaging is enabled.

option.label: 3-Omega Sweep
option.desc: Optimized parameters for 3-omega application. Averaging is enabled.

option.label: FRA (Sinc Filter)
option.desc: The sinc filter helps to speed up measurements for frequencies below 50 Hz in FRA mode. For higher frequencies it is automatically disabled. Averaging is off.

option.label: Impedance
option.desc: This application mode uses narrow bandwidth filter settings to achieve high calibration accuracy.

element.label: Precision
element.desc: Choose between a high speed scan speed or high precision and accuracy.

option.label: Low -> fast sweep
option.desc: Medium accuracy/precision is optimized for sweep speed.

option.label: High -> slow sweep
option.desc: High accuracy/precision takes more measurement time.

element.label: Bandwidth Mode
element.desc: Automatically is recommended in particular for logarithmic sweeps and assures the whole spectrum is covered.

option.label: Auto
option.desc: All bandwidth settings of the chosen demodulators are automatically adjusted. For logarithmic sweeps the measurement bandwidth is adjusted throughout the measurement.

option.label: Fixed
option.desc: Define a certain bandwidth which is taken for all chosen demodulators for the course of the measurement.

option.label: Manual
option.desc: The sweeper module leaves the demodulator bandwidth settings entirely untouched.

element.label: Time Constant/Bandwidth Select
element.desc: Defines the display unit of the low-pass filter to use for the sweep in fixed bandwidth mode: time constant (TC), noise equivalent power bandwidth (NEP), 3 dB bandwidth (3 dB).

option.label: TC
option.desc: Defines the low-pass filter characteristic using time constant of the filter.

option.label: Bandwidth NEP
option.desc: Defines the low-pass filter characteristic using the noise equivalent power bandwidth of the filter.

option.label: Bandwidth 3 dB
option.desc: Defines the low-pass filter characteristic using the cut-off frequency of the filter.

element.label: Time Constant/Bandwidth
element.desc: Defines the measurement bandwidth for Fixed bandwidth sweep mode, and corresponds to either noise equivalent power bandwidth (NEP), time constant (TC) or 3 dB bandwidth (3 dB) depending on selection.

element.label: Order
element.desc: Selects the filter roll off to use for the sweep in fixed bandwidth mode. Range between 6 dB/oct and 48 dB/oct.

element.label: Max Bandwidth (Hz)
element.desc: Maximal bandwidth used in auto bandwidth mode. The effective bandwidth will be calculated based on this max value, the frequency step size, and the omega suppression.
element.descExt: The NEP is correctly taken into account for demodulation bandwidths of up to 1.25 MHz.

element.label: BW Overlap
element.desc: If enabled the bandwidth of a sweep point may overlap with the frequency of neighboring sweep points. The effective bandwidth is only limited by the maximal bandwidth setting and omega suppression. As a result, the bandwidth is independent of the number of sweep points. For frequency response analysis bandwidth overlap should be enabled to achieve maximal sweep speed.

element.label: Omega Suppression (dB)
element.desc: Suppression of the omega and 2-omega components. Large suppression will have a significant impact on sweep time especially for low filter orders.

element.label: Min Settling Time (s)
element.desc: Minimum wait time in seconds between a sweep parameter change and the recording of the next sweep point. This parameter can be used to define the required settling time of the experimental setup. The effective wait time is the maximum of this value and the demodulator filter settling time determined from the Inaccuracy value specified.

element.label: Inaccuracy
element.desc: Demodulator filter settling inaccuracy defining the wait time between a sweep parameter change and recording of the next sweep point. The settling time is calculated as the time required to attain the specified remaining proportion [1e-13, 0.1] of an incoming step function. Typical inaccuracy values: 10 m for highest sweep speed for large signals, 100 u for precise amplitude measurements, 100 n for precise noise measurements. Depending on the order the settling accuracy will define the number of filter time constants the sweeper has to wait. The maximum between this value and the settling time is taken as wait time until the next sweep point is recorded.

element.label: Settling Time (TC)
element.desc: Calculated wait time expressed in time constants defined by the specified filter settling inaccuracy.

element.label: Algorithm
element.desc: Selects the measurement method.

option.label: Averaging
option.desc: Calculates the average on each data set.

option.label: Standard Deviation
option.desc: Calculates the standard deviation on each data set.

option.label: Average Power
option.desc: Calculates the electric power based on a 50 Ω input impedance.

element.label: Count (Sa)
element.desc: Sets the number of data samples per sweeper parameter point that is considered in the measurement. The maximum between this value and the next setting is taken as effective calculation time.

element.label: Count (TC)
element.desc: Sets the effective measurement time per sweeper parameter point that is considered in the measurement. The maximum between this value and the previous setting is taken as effective calculation time.

element.label: Phase Unwrap
element.desc: Allows for unwrapping of slowly changing phase evolutions around the +/-180 degree boundary.

element.label: Spectral Density
element.desc: Selects whether the result of the measurement is normalized versus the demodulation bandwidth.

element.label: Sinc Filter
element.desc: Enables sinc filter if sweep frequency is below 50 Hz. Will improve the sweep speed at low frequencies as omega components do not need to be suppressed by the normal low-pass filter.

element.label: AWG Control
element.desc: If enabled the sweeper starts automatically the AWG when a sweep is started. If sweeps are performed on nodes Index Sweep Triggers the AWG control is enabled automatically. Enable AWG control if some parameters should be recorded based on AWG generated signals.

element.label: History
element.desc: Each entry in the list corresponds to a single sweep in the history. The number of displayed sweeps is limited to 20. Use the toggle buttons to hide/display individual sweeps. Use the color picker to change the color of a sweep. Double click on an entry to edit its name.

element.label: Clear All
element.desc: Remove all records from the history list.

element.label: All
element.desc: Select all records from the history list.

element.label: None
element.desc: Deselect all records from the history list.

element.label: Reference
element.desc: Use the selected trace as reference for all active traces.

element.label: Length
element.desc: Maximum number of entries stored in the measurement history. The number of entries displayed in the list is limited to the most recent 100.

element.label: Reference On
element.desc: Enable/disable the reference mode.

element.label: Reference name
element.desc: Name of the reference trace used.

element.label: Save
element.desc: Save all sweeps in the history to file. Which data is saved depends on the demodulator channels present in the Vertical Axis Groups of the Control sub-tab.

element.label: Mode
element.desc: Selects the operation mode of the arithmetic unit

option.label: Add
option.desc: The arithmetic unit is in add mode: two independent demodulator outputs can be added together.

option.label: Divide
option.desc: The arithmetic unit is in divide mode: two independent demodulator outputs can be divided by each other.

option.label: Multiply
option.desc: The arithmetic unit is in multiply mode: two independent demodulator outputs can be multiplied with each other.

element.label: En
element.desc: Enables the streaming of results to the host computer.

option.label: ON
option.desc: The arithmetic unit is operative and results are streamed to the host computer.

option.label: OFF
option.desc: The arithmetic unit is operative but results are not streamed to the host computer.

element.label: Rate
element.desc: Defines the number of arithmetic unit result samples that are sent to the host computer per second.

element.label: Signal
element.desc: Select the arithmetic unit input signal

option.label: Demod X
option.desc: Use demodulator X (for Cartesian AU only).

option.label: Demod Y
option.desc: Use demodulator Y (for Cartesian AU only).

option.label: Boxcar
option.desc: Use Boxcar (for Cartesian AU only).

option.label: Demod R
option.desc: Use demodulator R (for polar AU only).

option.label: Demod Θ
option.desc: Use demodulator Θ (for polar AU only).

option.label: R(C1 + iC2)
option.desc: Use the magnitude of C1 + iC2 (for polar AU only).

option.label: Θ(C1 + iC2)
option.desc: Use the angle of C1 + iC2 (for polar AU only).

element.label: Channel
element.desc: Select demodulator and/or Boxcar channel number.

element.label: Coeff
element.desc: Select a coefficient to be applied to the selected Signal. Default: 1.

option.desc: A coefficient of 1 is used (default).

option.label: Aux In 1
option.desc: The signal on Aux In 1 is used as coefficient.

option.label: Aux In 2
option.desc: The signal on Aux In 2 is used as coefficient.

option.label: C1
option.desc: Output of Cartesian AU 1 (C1) is used as coefficient (for Cartesian AU only).

option.label: C2
option.desc: Output of Cartesian AU 2 (C2) is used as coefficient (for Cartesian AU only).

option.label: P1
option.desc: Output of Polar AU 1 (P1) is used as coefficient (for Polar AU only).

option.label: P2
option.desc: Output of Polar AU 2 (P2) is used as coefficient (for Polar AU only).

element.label: Scale
element.desc: Custom scaling factor.

element.label: Unit
element.desc: Unit of "Scale", for example "m/V".

element.label: Result value
element.desc: Shows the result of the arithmetic unit.

element.label: Result unit
element.desc: Shows the unit of the result of the arithmetic unit. If the unit formula is not valid, it will be indicated as #Invalid! and invalid formula can be corrected by adjusting scaling units.

element.label: Overflow
element.desc: When red, indicates that an overflow has occurred in the arithmetic unit.

element.label: Auxiliary Input Voltage
element.desc: Voltage measured at the Auxiliary Input.

element.label: Signal
element.desc: Select the signal source to be represented on the Auxiliary Output.

option.label: X, Y, R, Θ
option.desc: Select any of the 4 demodulator output quantities of any of the demodulators for auxiliary output.

option.label: PID Out
option.desc: Use one of the PID controllers output. UHF-PID option needs to be installed.

option.label: PLL df
option.desc: Use one of the PLL delta frequencies result. HF2LI-PLL option needs to be installed.

option.label: PID Shift
option.desc: Use one of the PID controllers shift results. UHF-PID option needs to be installed.

option.label: PID Out
option.desc: Use one of the PID controllers output. HF2LI-PID option needs to be installed.

option.label: Boxcar
option.desc: Select one of the two Boxcar units for auxiliary output. UHF-BOX option needs to be installed.

option.label: AU Cartesian
option.desc: Select one of the two Arithmetic Cartesian units for auxiliary output.

option.label: AU Polar
option.desc: Select one of the two Arithmetic Polar units for auxiliary output.

option.label: AWG
option.desc: Select one of the AWG channels for auxiliary output when running the AWG in four-channel mode. UHF-AWG option needs to be installed.

option.label: Manual
option.desc: Manually define an auxiliary output voltage using the offset field.

element.label: Channel
element.desc: Select the channel according to the selected signal source.

element.label: Preoffset
element.desc: Add an pre-offset to the signal before scaling is applied. Auxiliary Output Value = (Signal+Preoffset)*Scale + Offset

element.label: Auto-zero
element.desc: Automatically adjusts the Pre-offset to set the Auxiliary Output Value to zero.

element.label: Scale
element.desc: Multiplication factor to scale the signal. Auxiliary Output Value = (Signal+Preoffset)*Scale + Offset

element.label: Auto-zero
element.desc: Automatically adjusts the Offset to set the Auxiliary Output Value to zero.

element.label: Offset
element.desc: Add the specified offset voltage to the signal after scaling. Auxiliary Output Value = (Signal+Preoffset)*Scale + Offset

element.label: Lower Limit
element.desc: Lower limit for the signal at the Auxiliary Output. A smaller value will be clipped.

element.label: Upper Limit
element.desc: Upper limit for the signal at the Auxiliary Output. A larger value will be clipped.

element.label: Value
element.desc: Voltage present on the Auxiliary Output. Auxiliary Output Value = (Signal+Preoffset)*Scale + Offset

element.label: DIO mode
element.desc: Select DIO mode

option.label: Normal
option.desc: Manual setting of the DIO output value.

option.label: AWG Sequencer
option.desc: Enables setting of DIO output values by AWG sequencer commands.

element.label: DIO bits
element.desc: Partitioning of the 32 bits of the DIO into 4 buses of 8 bits each. Each bus can be used as an input or output.

element.label: DIO input
element.desc: Current digital values at the DIO input port.

custom.label: numeric value in either Hex or Binary format

element.label: DIO output
element.desc: Digital output values. Enable drive to apply the signals to the output.

custom.label: numeric value in either hexadecimal or binary format

element.label: DIO drive
element.desc: When on, the corresponding 8-bit bus is in output mode. When off, it is in input mode.

element.label: Format
element.desc: Select DIO view format.

option.label: hex
option.desc: DIO view format is hexadecimal.

option.label: binary
option.desc: DIO view format is binary.

element.label: Clock
element.desc: Select DIO internal or external clocking.

option.label: Internal 60 MHz
option.desc: The DIO is internally clocked with a fixed frequency of 60 MHz.

option.label: Internal 64 MHz
option.desc: The DIO is internally clocked with a fixed frequency of 64 MHz.

option.label: Internal 56 MHz
option.desc: The DIO is internally clocked with a fixed frequency of 56.25 MHz.

option.label: Clk Pin 68
option.desc: The DIO is externally clocked with a clock signal connected to DIO Pin 68.
option.descExt: Available frequency range 1 Hz to 60 MHz.
Available frequency range 1 Hz to 64 MHz.
Available frequency range 1 Hz to 56.25 MHz.

element.label: Sync Bit 1
element.desc: Select a demodulator reference signal to be applied on DIO 1.

option.label: Off
option.desc: DIO output 1 (BNC connector) is not used for sync output and is free for other purposes.

option.label: Demod 1 to 8
option.desc: Reference signal of the selected demodulator is output on DIO 1. Note: there is a 166 ns delay between the sync on DIO 1 and the front panel outputs (sync on DIO 1 comes first) which leads to a relevant phase shift at high frequencies.

element.label: Sync Bit 0
element.desc: Select a demodulator reference signal to be applied on DIO 0.

option.label: Off
option.desc: DIO output 0 (BNC connector) is not used for sync output and is free for other purposes.

option.label: Demod 1 to 8
option.desc: Reference signal of the selected demodulator is output on DIO 0. Note: there is a 166 ns delay between the sync on DIO 0 and the front panel outputs (sync on DIO 0 comes first) which leads to a relevant phase shift at high frequencies.

element.label: Trigger level
element.desc: Trigger voltage level at which the trigger input toggles between low and high. Use 50% amplitude for digital input and consider 100 mV hysteresis.

element.label: 50 Ω
element.desc: Trigger input impedance: When on, the trigger input impedance is 50 Ω, when off 1 kΩ.

element.label: Trigger Input status
element.desc: Indicates the current trigger state.

option.label: high
option.desc: A high state has been triggered.

option.label: low
option.desc: A low state has been triggered.

option.label: toggling
option.desc: The trigger signal is toggling.

element.label: Trigger output signal
element.desc: Select the signal assigned to the trigger output.

option.label: Off
option.desc: The output trigger is disabled.

option.label: Osc Phase Demod 2
option.desc: Trigger event is output for each zero crossing of the oscillator phase used on demodulator 2.

option.label: Osc Phase Demod 4
option.desc: Trigger event is output for each zero crossing of the oscillator phase used on demodulator 4.

option.label: Osc Phase Demod 4
option.desc: Trigger event is output for each zero crossing of the oscillator phase used on demodulator 4.

option.label: Osc Phase Demod 8
option.desc: Trigger event is output for each zero crossing of the oscillator phase used on demodulator 8.

option.label: Scope Trigger
option.desc: Trigger output is asserted when the scope trigger condition is satisfied.

option.label: Scope /Trigger
option.desc: Trigger output is deasserted when the scope trigger condition is satisfied.

option.label: Scope Armed
option.desc: Trigger output is asserted when the scope is waiting for the trigger condition to become satisfied.

option.label: Scope /Armed
option.desc: Trigger output is deasserted when the scope is waiting for the trigger condition to become satisfied.

option.label: Scope Active
option.desc: Trigger output is asserted when the scope has triggered and is recording data.

option.label: Scope /Active
option.desc: Trigger output is deasserted when the scope has triggered and is recording data.

option.label: AWG Trigger 1-4
option.desc: Trigger output is assigned to one of the AWG Trigger channels controlled by AWG sequencer commands.

option.label: AWG Marker 1-4
option.desc: Trigger output is assigned to one of the AWG Marker channels attached to AWG waveform data.

option.label: AWG Active
option.desc: Trigger output is asserted when the AWG is enabled.

option.label: AWG Waiting
option.desc: Trigger output is asserted when the AWG is waiting for external triggers, for a clock timer, or for other events.

option.label: AWG Fetching
option.desc: Trigger output is asserted when the AWG is fetching data from the main waveform and instruction memory.

option.label: AWG Playing
option.desc: Trigger output is asserted when the AWG is playing waveforms.

element.label: Width
element.desc: Defines the minimal pulse width for trigger events signaled on the trigger outputs of the device.

element.label: Delay
element.desc: Trigger delay, controls the fine delay of the trigger output. The resolution is 78 ps.

element.label: Trigger drive
element.desc: When on, the bidirectional trigger on the front panel is in output mode. When off, the trigger is in input mode.

element.label: About
element.desc: Get information about LabOne software.

element.label: Web Server Rev
element.desc: Web Server revision number

element.label: Host
element.desc: IP-Address of the LabOne Web Server

element.label: Port
element.desc: LabOne Web Server TCP/IP port

element.label: Data Server Rev
element.desc: Data Server revision number

element.label: Host
element.desc: IP-Address of the LabOne Data Server

element.label: Port
element.desc: TCP/IP port used to connect to the LabOne Data Server.

element.label: Connect/Disconnect
element.desc: Connect/disconnect the LabOne Data Server of the currently selected device. If a LabOne Data Server is connected only devices that are visible to that specific server are shown in the device list.

element.label: Connectivity
element.desc: Forbid/Allow to connect to this Data Server from other computers.

element.label: File Upload
element.desc: Drag and drop files in this box to upload files. Clicking on the box opens a file dialog for file upload.
element.descExt: Supported files: Settings (*.xml), software update (LabOne*.tar). Uploading software updates will automatically trigger the update process if the file is valid and has a different revision than the currently installed software.
Supported files: Settings (*.xml).
Supported files: Settings (*.xml).

element.label: Current Session
element.desc: Session identifier. A session is a connection between a client and LabOne Data Server. Also indicated in status bar.

element.label: Session Dialog
element.desc: Open the session dialog window. This allows for device or session change. The current session can be continued by pressing cancel.

element.label: File Name
element.desc: Save/load the device and user interface settings to/from the selected file on the internal flash drive. The setting files can be downloaded/uploaded using the Files tab.
Save/load the device and user interface settings to/from the selected file. File location: [user]\AppData\Roaming\Zurich Instruments\LabOne\WebServer\setting

element.label: Include Device
element.desc: Enable save/load of device settings.

element.label: Include UI
element.desc: Enable save/load of user interface settings.

element.label: Load Preferences
element.desc: Enable loading of user preferences from settings file.

element.label: Save
element.desc: Save the user interface and device setting to a file.

element.label: Load
element.desc: Load the user interface and device setting from a file.

element.label: Load From USB
element.desc: Load public SSH keys from the USB mass storage connected to the device. Uploading of SSH keys enables SSH access to the device.

element.label: Delete All
element.desc: Delete all public SSH keys on the device.

element.label: Display Theme
element.desc: Choose theme of the user interface.

element.label: Print Theme
element.desc: Choose theme for printing SVG plots

element.label: Grid
element.desc: Select active grid setting for all graphs.

element.label: Resampling Method
element.desc: Select the resampling interpolation method. Resampling corrects for sample misalignment in subsequent scope shots. This is important when using reduced sample rates with a time resolution below that of the trigger.

option.label: Linear
option.desc: Linear interpolation

option.label: pchip
option.desc: Piecewise Cubic Hermite Interpolating Polynomial

element.label: Show Shortcuts
element.desc: Displays a list of keyboard and mouse wheel shortcuts for manipulating plots.

element.label: Dynamic Tabs
element.desc: If enabled, sections inside the application tabs are collapsed automatically depending on the window width.

element.label: Lock-In Mode
element.desc: Select the display mode for the Graphical Lock-in tab. Auto format will select the format which fits best the current window width.

element.label: Log Format
element.desc: Choose the command log format. See status bar and [User]\Documents\Zurich Instruments\LabOne\WebServer\Log

element.label: CSV Delimiter
element.desc: Select which delimiter to insert for CSV files.

element.label: Auto Start
element.desc: Skip session dialog at start-up if selected device is available.
element.descExt: In case of an error or disconnected device the session dialog will be reactivated.

element.label: Update Reminder
element.desc: Display a reminder on startup if the LabOne software wasn't updated in 180 days.

element.label: Drive
element.desc: Select the drive for data saving.

option.label: MF Flash Drive
option.desc: Internal flash mass storage device of the MFLI/MFIA.

option.label: PC Storage Drive
option.desc: Storage of the PC on which the LabOne Web Server is running.

option.label: USB 1/2
option.desc: Mass storage device connected on USB.

element.label: Format
element.desc: Data format of recorded data.

element.label: Folder
element.desc: Folder containing the saved data.

element.label: Queue
element.desc: Number of data chunks not yet written to disk.

element.label: Size
element.desc: Accumulated size of saved data.

element.label: Record
element.desc: Start and stop saving data to disk as defined in the selection filter. Length of the files is determined by the Window Length setting in the Plotter tab.

element.label: Display
element.desc: Display specific tree branches using one of the preset view filters or a custom regular expression.

element.label: Tree
element.desc: Click on a tree node to activate it.

element.label: All
element.desc: Select all tree elements.

element.label: None
element.desc: Deselect all tree elements.

element.label: Serial
element.desc: Device serial number

element.label: Type
element.desc: Device type

element.label: Hardware
element.desc: Hardware revision of the instrument

element.label: FPGA
element.desc: HDL firmware revision

element.label: Digital Board
element.desc: Hardware revision of the FPGA base board

element.label: Analog Board
element.desc: Hardware revision of the analog board

element.label: Firmware
element.desc: Revision of the device internal controller software

element.label: FX2 USB
element.desc: USB firmware revision

element.label: Installed Options
element.desc: Options that are installed on this device

element.label: Install
element.desc: Click to install options on this device. Requires a unique feature code and a power cycle after entry.

element.label: Clock Source
element.desc: 10 MHz reference clock source.

option.label: Internal
