option.desc: Internal 10 MHz clock is used as the frequency and time base reference.

option.label: Clk 10 MHz
option.desc: An external 10-MHz clock is used as the frequency and time base reference. Provide a clean and stable 10 MHz reference to the appropriate back panel connector.

element.label: Power Alert
element.desc: Check 115 V/230 V settings if active. Active if 5 V supply drops below 4.8 V.

element.label: Jumbo Frames
element.desc: Enables jumbo frames (4k) on the TCP/IP interface. This will reduce the load on the PC and is required to achieve maximal throughput. Make sure that jumbo frames (4k) are enabled on the network card as well.
element.descExt: If one of the devices on the network is not able to work with jumbo frames, the connection will fail.

element.label: Enabled
element.desc: Enables an automatic instrument self calibration about 16 min after start up.
element.descExt: In order to guarantee the full specification, it is recommended to perform a self calibration after warm-up of the device.

element.label: Time interval
element.desc: Time interval for which the self calibration is valid. After this time it is recommended to rerun the auto calibration. A LED indicator in the status bar indicates when another self calibration is recommended.

element.label: Calibration temperature threshold
element.desc: When the temperature changes by the specified amount, it is recommended to rerun the self calibration. A LED indicator in the status bar indicates when another self calibration is recommended.

element.label: Next calibration
element.desc: Remaining seconds until the first calibration is executed or a recalibration is requested.

element.label: Manual self calibration
element.desc: Initiate self calibration to improve input digitizer linearity.

element.label: Time Zone
element.desc: Select the time zone in which the device is used. Settings, data and log files receive timestamps from this time zone. Requires a power cycle for changes to become effective.

custom.label: Timezone offset from UTC (Coordinated Universal Time).

element.label: Index
element.desc: Select between factory preset or presets stored in internal flash memory.

option.label: Factory
option.desc: Select factory preset.

option.label: Flash 1-6
option.desc: Select one of the presets stored in internal flash memory 1-6.

element.label: Load
element.desc: Load the selected preset.

element.label: Save
element.desc: Save the actual setting as preset.

element.label: Erase
element.desc: Erase the selected preset.

element.label: Busy
element.desc: Indicates that the device is busy with either loading, saving or erasing a preset.

element.label: Error
element.desc: Returns a 0 if the last preset operation was successfully completed or 1 if the last preset operation was illegal.

option.desc: Last preset operation was successfully completed.
Last preset operation was illegal.

element.label: Error LED
element.desc: Turns red if the last operation was illegal.

element.label: Valid LED
element.desc: Turns green if a valid preset is stored at the respective location.

element.label: Presets
element.desc: Shows a list of available presets including factory preset.

option.desc: Factory default preset. The name of the factory default preset is given and can not be edited.
Flash preset 1. The name of this preset can be edited.
Flash preset 2. The name of this preset can be edited.
Flash preset 3. The name of this preset can be edited.
Flash preset 4. The name of this preset can be edited.
Flash preset 5. The name of this preset can be edited.
Flash preset 6. The name of this preset can be edited.

element.label: Default
element.desc: Indicates the preset which is used as default preset at start-up of the device.

option.label: Factory
option.desc: Select factory preset as default preset.

option.label: Flash 1-6
option.desc: Select one of the presets stored in internal flash memory 1-6 as default preset.

element.label: Interface
element.desc: Active interface between device and data server. In case multiple options are available, the priority as indicated on the left applies.

element.label: IPv4 Address
element.desc: Current IP address of the device. This IP address is assigned dynamically by a DHCP server, defined statically, or is a fall-back IP address if the DHCP server could not be found (for point to point connections).

element.label: Jumbo Frames
element.desc: Enable jumbo frames for this device and interface as default.

element.label: Static IP
element.desc: Enable this flag if the device is used in a network with fixed IP assignment without a DHCP server.

element.label: IPv4 Address
element.desc: Static IP address to be written to the device.

element.label: IPv4 Mask
element.desc: Static IP mask to be written to the device.

element.label: Gateway
element.desc: Static IP gateway

element.label: Program
element.desc: Click to program the specified IPv4 address, IPv4 Mask and Gateway to the device.

element.label: Pending
element.desc: Number of buffers ready for receiving command packets from the device.

element.label: Processing
element.desc: Number of buffers being processed for command packets. Small values indicate proper performance. For a TCP/IP interface, command packets are sent using the TCP protocol.

element.label: Packet Loss
element.desc: Number of command packets lost since device start. Command packets contain device settings that are sent to and received from the device.

element.label: Bandwidth
element.desc: Command streaming bandwidth usage on the physical network connection between device and data server.

element.label: Pending
element.desc: Number of buffers ready for receiving data packets from the device.

element.label: Processing
element.desc: Number of buffers being processed for data packets. Small values indicate proper performance. For a TCP/IP interface, data packets are sent using the UDP protocol.

element.label: Packet Loss
element.desc: Number of data packets lost since device start. Data packets contain measurement data.

element.label: Bandwidth
element.desc: Data streaming bandwidth usage on the physical network connection between device and data server.

element.label: FW Load
element.desc: Indicates the CPU load on the processor where the firmware is running.

element.label: CPU Load
element.desc: Indicates the total CPU load on the machine where the data server is running.

element.label: Memory Usage
element.desc: Indicates the total memory usage of the machine where the data server is running.

element.label: Data received (MB/s)
element.desc: USB data rate: Current USB data rate from the device to the host PC

element.label: USB FIFO Level (%)
element.desc: USB FIFO level: Indicates the USB FIFO fill level inside the device. When 100%, data is lost

element.label: New Folder
element.desc: Create new folder at current location.

element.label: Rename
element.desc: Rename selected file or folder.

element.label: Delete
element.desc: Delete selected file(s) and/or folder(s).

element.label: Copy
element.desc: Copy selected file(s) and/or folder(s) to Clipboard.

element.label: Cut
element.desc: Cut selected file(s) and/or folder(s) to Clipboard.

element.label: Paste
element.desc: Paste file(s) and/or folder(s) from Clipboard to the selected directory.

element.label: Upload
element.desc: Upload file(s) and/or folder(s) to the selected directory.

element.label: Download
element.desc: Download selected file(s) and/or folder(s).

element.label: Enable
element.desc: Enable the PLL (i.e. the associated PID controller)
Enable the PLL

element.label: Input
element.desc: Select the input signal of the PLL controller

custom.label: Sig In 1/2, Aux In 1/2, DIO D0/1

element.label: TC Mode
element.desc: Switch between display of gain parameters (I, D) and time constants (Ti, Td) for the integral and differential parts. The following relations hold: I=P/Ti, D=P*Td.

element.label: Harmonic
element.desc: Set the harmonic used in the phase detector. A setting of 2 means the PLL generates a sub-harmonic of the external reference.

element.label: Oscillator
element.desc: Oscillator controlled by the PLL

element.label: Center Freq (Hz)
element.desc: Center frequency of the PLL oscillator. The PLL frequency shift is relative to this center frequency.

element.label: Range
element.desc: Set the frequency range of the PLL controller output relative to the center frequency

element.label: Auto Center Frequency
element.desc: The PLL Center Frequency is determined automatically. In this mode, the instrument sweeps the operating range until it finds a suitable frequency. Note: Auto Center Frequency works only for open loop systems. Closed loop systems require manual mode.

element.label: Auto Adjust
element.desc: Adjust the center so that the frequency shift is zero.

element.label: Upper Limit (Hz)
element.desc: Upper frequency limit of the PLL oscillator. The PLL frequency is clamped between Center + Lower Limit and Center + Upper Limit.

element.label: Lower Limit (Hz)
element.desc: Lower frequency limit of the PLL oscillator. The PLL frequency is clamped between Center + Lower Limit and Center + Upper Limit.

element.label: Demodulator
element.desc: Select the demodulator that is used as the phase detector of the PLL.

element.label: TC (s)
element.desc: Filter time constant of the demodulator used as the phase detector.

element.label: Auto TC Enable
element.desc: When On, the PLL is running at full bandwidth. Use manual mode (off) for low-noise performance.

element.label: Demod BW (Hz)
element.desc: Filter bandwidth of the demodulator used as the phase detector.

element.label: Order
element.desc: Filter order of the demodulator used as the phase detector.

element.label: Order
element.desc: Filter order of the input demodulator

element.label: Setpoint (deg)
element.desc: Phase set point in degrees (i.e. PID setpoint). Controls the phase difference between the input signal and the generated signal.

element.label: Automated adjustment of PID coefficients
element.desc: If turned on together with Auto TC Enable and Auto Center Frequency, the PLL is in ExtRef mode

element.label: Phase Unwrap
element.desc: Enables the phase error unwrapping up to +/-32pi.

element.label: P (Hz/deg)
element.desc: PID proportional gain P

element.label: I (Hz/deg/s)
element.desc: PID integral gain I

element.label: D (Hz/deg*s)
element.desc: PID derivative gain D

element.label: D Limit TC
element.desc: Time constant of the low-pass filter for the D gain limitation. When 0, the low-pass filter is disabled.

element.label: Rate (Hz)
element.desc: Current sampling rate of the PLL control loop.
element.descExt: Note: The numerical precision of the controller is influenced by the loop filter sampling rate. If the target bandwidth is below 1 kHz is starts to make sense to adjust this rate to a value of about 100 to 500 times the target bandwidth. If the rate is set too high for low-bandwidth applications, integration inaccuracies can lead to nonlinear behavior.

element.label: Error (deg)
element.desc: Current phase error of the PLL (Set Point - PID Input).

element.label: PLL lock LED
element.desc: Indicates when the PLL is locked.
element.descExt: The PLL error is sampled at 5 Sa/s and its absolute value is calculated. If the result is smaller than 5 degrees the loop is considered locked.

element.label: Freq Shift (Hz)
element.desc: Current frequency shift of the PLL (Oscillator Freq - Center Freq).

element.label: To Advisor
element.desc: Copy the current PLL settings to the PLL Advisor.

element.label: Advanced
element.desc: Enables manual selection of display and advice properties. If disabled the display and advise settings are automatically with optimized default values.

element.label: Display
element.desc: Select the display mode used for rendering the system frequency or time response.

option.label: Bode Magnitude
option.desc: Display the Bode magnitude plot.

option.label: Bode Phase
option.desc: Display the Bode phase plot.

option.label: Step Resp
option.desc: Display the step response plot.

element.label: Start (Hz)
element.desc: Start frequency for Bode plot display. For disabled advanced mode the start value is automatically derived from the system properties and the input field is read-only.

element.label: Stop (Hz)
element.desc: Stop frequency for Bode plot display. For disabled advanced mode the stop value is automatically derived from the system properties and the input field is read-only.

element.label: Start (s)
element.desc: Start time for step response display. For disabled advanced mode the start value is zero and the field is read-only.

element.label: Stop (s)
element.desc: Stop time for step response display. For disabled advanced mode the stop value is automatically derived from the system properties and the input field is read-only.

element.label: Response In
element.desc: Start point for the plant response simulation for open or closed loops. In closed loop configuration all elements from output to input will be included as feedback elements.

option.label: Demod Input
option.desc: Start point is at the demodulator input.

option.label: Setpoint
option.desc: Start point is at the setpoint in front of the PID.

option.label: PID Output
option.desc: Start point is at PID output.

option.label: Instrument Output
option.desc: Start point is at the instrument output.

option.label: DUT Output
option.desc: Start point is at the DUT output and instrument input.

element.label: Response Out
element.desc: End point for the plant response simulation for open or closed loops. In closed loop configuration all elements from output to input will be included as feedback elements.

option.label: PID Output
option.desc: End point is at PID output.

option.label: Instrument Output
option.desc: End point is at the instrument output.

option.label: DUT Output
option.desc: End point is at the DUT output and instrument input.

option.label: Demod Input
option.desc: End point is at the demodulator input.

option.label: PID Error
option.desc: End point is at the PID error calculation of the PID.

element.label: Closed-Loop
element.desc: Switches the display of the system response between closed or open loop.

element.label: Target BW (Hz)
element.desc: Target bandwidth for the PLL closed loop feedback system which is used for the advising of the PID parameters. This bandwidth defines the trade-off between PLL speed and phase noise.

element.label: Auto Bandwidth
element.desc: Adjusts the demodulator bandwidth to fit best to the specified target bandwidth of the full system. If disabled, a demodulator bandwidth too close to the target bandwidth may cause overshoot and instability.
element.descExt: In special cases the demodulator bandwidth can also be selected smaller than the target bandwidth.

element.label: Advise Mode
element.desc: Select the PID coefficients that are optimized. The other PID coefficients remain unchanged but are used during optimization. This allows to force coefficients to a value while optimizing the rest.
element.descExt: The advise time will increase significantly with the number of parameters optimized.

option.label: P
option.desc: Only optimize the proportional gain.

option.label: I
option.desc: Only optimize the integral gain.

option.label: PI
option.desc: Only optimize the proportional and the integral gain.

option.label: PID
option.desc: Optimize the proportional, integral, and derivative gains.

option.label: PIDF
option.desc: Optimize the proportional, integral, and derivative gains. Also the derivative gain bandwidth will be optimized.

element.label: Advise
element.desc: Calculate PID coefficients based on application mode and given settings.
element.descExt: Only PID coefficients specified with the advise mode are optimized. The Advise mode can be used incremental, means current coefficients are used as starting point for the optimization unless other model parameters are changed in-between.

element.label: P (Hz/deg)
element.desc: Proportional gain P coefficient used for calculation of the response of the PID model. The parameter can be optimized with PID advise or changed manually. The parameter only gets active on the PID after pressing the button To PLL.

element.label: I (Hz/deg/s)
element.desc: Integral gain I coefficient used for calculation of the response of the PID model. The parameter can be optimized with PID advise or changed manually. The parameter only gets active on the PID after pressing the button To PLL.

element.label: D (Hz/deg*s)
element.desc: Derivative gain D coefficient used for calculation of the response of the PID model. The parameter can be optimized with PID advise or changed manually. The parameter only gets active on the PID after pressing the button To PLL.

element.label: Rate (Hz)
element.desc: PID sampling rate used for simulation.
element.descExt: The advisor will update the rate to match with the specified target bandwidth. A sampling rate close to the target bandwidth and excessive higher bandwidth will results in a simulation mismatch.

element.label: BW (Hz)
element.desc: Simulated bandwidth of the full close loop PLL with the current PID settings. This value should be larger than the target bandwidth.

element.label: Target BW LED
element.desc: Green indicates that the target bandwidth can be achieved. For very high PLL bandwidth the target bandwidth might be only achieved using marginal stable PID settings.

element.label: PM (deg)
element.desc: Simulated phase margin of the PID with the current settings. The phase margin should be greater than 45 deg for stable conditions. An Infinite value is shown if no unity gain crossing is available to determine a phase margin.

element.label: Stable LED
element.desc: Green indicates that the phase margin is fulfilled and the PID system should be stable.

element.label: To PLL
element.desc: Copy the PLL Advisor settings to the PLL.

element.label: Advanced Mode
element.desc: Enables manual tuning of the PID parameters. The stability is reported and the frequency response is shown on the plots.

element.label: Application
element.desc: Select PLL Advisor mode. Currently only one mode is supported.

element.label: Target BW (Hz)
element.desc: Requested PLL bandwidth. Higher loop filter bandwidth can be attained by manual tuning only.

element.label: Advise
element.desc: Calculate PLL settings based on application mode and given settings.

element.label: Demod BW (Hz)
element.desc: Demodulator bandwidth used for the PLL loop filter

element.label: Order
element.desc: Demodulator order used for the PLL loop filter

element.label: P (Hz/deg)
element.desc: PLL Advisor proportional gain P

element.label: I (Hz/deg/s)
element.desc: PLL Advisor integral gain I

element.label: D (Hz/deg*s)
element.desc: PLL Advisor derivative gain D

element.label: Rate (Hz)
element.desc: PLL Advisor sampling rate of the PLL control loop

element.label: PM (deg)
element.desc: Simulated phase margin of the PLL with the current settings. The phase margin should be greater than 45 deg and preferably greater than 65 deg for stable conditions.

element.label: Advisor stability LED
element.desc: When green, the PLL Advisor found a stable solution with the given settings. When red, revise your settings and rerun the PLL Advisor.

element.label: PLL BW (Hz)
element.desc: Simulated bandwidth of the PLL with the current settings. The bandwidth is roughly equal to the locking range of the PLL.

element.label: Model BW LED
element.desc: Red indicates the simulated PLL BW is smaller than the Target BW.

element.label: To PLL
element.desc: Copy the PLL Advisor settings to the PLL.

element.label: Enable
element.desc: Enable the PID controller

element.label: Input
element.desc: Select input source of PID controller

element.label: Input Channel
element.desc: Select input channel of PID controller.

element.label: Setpoint
element.desc: PID controller setpoint

element.label: TC Mode
element.desc: Enables time constant representation of PID parameters.

element.label: Phase Unwrap
element.desc: Enables the phase error unwrapping up to +/-32pi.

element.label: Output
element.desc: Select output of the PID controller

option.label: Sig Out 1/2 Amplitude
option.desc: Feedback to the main signal output amplitudes

option.label: Oscillator Frequency
option.desc: Feedback to any of the internal oscillator frequencies

option.label: Demodulator Phase
option.desc: Feedback to any of the 8 demodulator phase set points

option.label: Aux Output Offset
option.desc: Feedback to any of the 4 Auxiliary Output's Offset

option.label: Signal Output Offset
option.desc: Feedback to the main Signal Output offset adjustment

option.label: Output 1 Amplitude
option.desc: Feedback to the main signal output amplitudes

option.label: Output 2 Amplitude
option.desc: Feedback to the main signal output amplitudes

option.label: Oscillator Frequency
option.desc: Feedback to any of the internal oscillator frequencies

option.label: Aux Output Offset
option.desc: Feedback to any of the 4 Auxiliary Output's Offset

option.label: DIO (int16)
option.desc: Feedback to the DIO as a 16 bit word

element.label: Output Channel
element.desc: Select output channel of PID controller.

element.label: Center, Upper, Lower Limit
Center, Range
element.desc: After adding the Center value to the PID output, the signal is clamped to Center + Lower Limit and Center + Upper Limit.
After adding the Center value to the PID output, the signal is clamped to Center + Range and Center - Range.

element.label: Range
element.desc: Set the range of the PID controller output relative to the center

element.label: P (Hz/deg)
element.desc: PID proportional gain P

element.label: I (Hz/deg/s)
element.desc: PID integral gain I

element.label: D (Hz/deg*s)
element.desc: PID derivative gain D

element.label: D Limit TC/BW 3 dB
element.desc: The cutoff of the low-pass filter for the D limitation, shown as either the filter time constant or the 3 dB cutoff frequency, depending on the selected TC mode. When set to 0, the low-pass filter is disabled.

custom.label: TBD
102 ns to 2.33 ms/68.3 Hz to 1.56 MHz

element.label: Rate
element.desc: PID sampling rate and update rate of PID outputs. Needs to be set substantially higher than the targeted loop filter bandwidth.
element.descExt: Note: The numerical precision of the controller is influenced by the loop filter sampling rate. If the target bandwidth is below 1 kHz is starts to make sense to adjust this rate to a value of about 100 to 500 times the target bandwidth. If the rate is set to high for low bandwidth applications, integration inaccuracies can lead to non linear behavior.

element.label: Error
element.desc: Error = Set point - PID Input

element.label: Shift
element.desc: Difference between the current output value Out and the Center. Shift = P*Error + I*Int(Error, dt) + D*dError/dt

element.label: Out
element.desc: Current output value

element.label: Tune
element.desc: Optimize the PID parameters so that the noise of the closed-loop system gets minimized. The tuning method needs a proper starting point for optimization (away from the limits). The tuning process can be interrupted and restarted.
element.descExt: The tuning will try to match the PID bandwidth with the loop bandwidth of the DUT, signal input (demodulator), and signal output.

element.label: Max Rate (Sa/s)
element.desc: Target Rate for PID output data sent to PC. This value defines the applied decimation for sending data to the PC. It does not affect the Aux Output.

element.label: Decimation
element.desc: Decimation factor applied to ensure a sampling rate smaller than the Max Rate set.

element.label: To Advisor
element.desc: Copy the current PID settings to the PID Advisor.

element.label: Advanced
element.desc: Enables manual selection of display and advice properties. If disabled the display and advise settings are automatically with optimized default values.

element.label: Display
element.desc: Select the display mode used for rendering the system frequency or time response.

option.label: Bode Magnitude
option.desc: Display the Bode magnitude plot.

option.label: Bode Phase
option.desc: Display the Bode phase plot.

option.label: Step Resp
option.desc: Display the step response plot.

element.label: Start (Hz)
element.desc: Start frequency for Bode plot display. For disabled advanced mode the start value is automatically derived from the system properties and the input field is read-only.

element.label: Stop (Hz)
element.desc: Stop frequency for Bode plot display. For disabled advanced mode the stop value is automatically derived from the system properties and the input field is read-only.

element.label: Start (s)
element.desc: Start time for step response display. For disabled advanced mode the start value is zero and the field is read-only.

element.label: Stop (s)
element.desc: Stop time for step response display. For disabled advanced mode the stop value is automatically derived from the system properties and the input field is read-only.

element.label: Response In
element.desc: Start point for the plant response simulation for open or closed loops. In closed loop configuration all elements from output to input will be included as feedback elements.

option.label: Demod Input
option.desc: Start point is at the demodulator input.

option.label: Setpoint
option.desc: Start point is at the setpoint in front of the PID.

option.label: PID Output
option.desc: Start point is at PID output.

option.label: Instrument Output
option.desc: Start point is at the instrument output.

option.label: DUT Output
option.desc: Start point is at the DUT output and instrument input.

element.label: Response Out
element.desc: End point for the plant response simulation for open or closed loops. In closed loop configuration all elements from output to input will be included as feedback elements.

option.label: PID Output
option.desc: End point is at PID output.

option.label: Instrument Output
option.desc: End point is at the instrument output.

option.label: DUT Output
option.desc: End point is at the DUT output and instrument input.

option.label: Demod Input
option.desc: End point is at the demodulator input.

option.label: PID Error
option.desc: End point is at the PID error calculation of the PID.

element.label: Closed-Loop
element.desc: Switch the display of the system response between closed or open loop.

element.label: Target BW (Hz)
element.desc: Target bandwidth for the closed loop feedback system which is used for the advising of the PID parameters. This bandwidth defines the trade-off between PID speed and noise.

element.label: Auto Bandwidth
element.desc: Adjusts the demodulator bandwidth to fit best to the specified target bandwidth of the full system. If disabled, a demodulator bandwidth too close to the target bandwidth may cause overshoot and instability.
element.descExt: In special cases the demodulator bandwidth can also be selected smaller than the target bandwidth.

element.label: Advise Mode
element.desc: Select the PID coefficients that are optimized. The other PID coefficients remain unchanged but are used during optimization. This allows to force coefficients to a value while optimizing the rest.
element.descExt: The advise time will increase significantly with the number of parameters optimized.

option.label: P
option.desc: Only optimize the proportional gain.

option.label: I
option.desc: Only optimize the integral gain.

option.label: PI
option.desc: Only optimize the proportional and the integral gain.

option.label: PID
option.desc: Optimize the proportional, integral, and derivative gains.

option.label: PIDF
option.desc: Optimize the proportional, integral, and derivative gains. Also the derivative gain bandwidth will be optimized.

element.label: Advise
element.desc: Calculate the PID coefficients based on the used DUT model and the given target bandwidth. If optimized values can be found the coefficients are updated and the response curve is updated on the plot.
element.descExt: Only PID coefficients specified with the advise mode are optimized. The Advise mode can be used incremental, means current coefficients are used as starting point for the optimization unless other model parameters are changed in-between.

element.label: P (Hz/deg)
element.desc: Proportional gain P coefficient used for calculation of the response of the PID model. The parameter can be optimized with PID advise or changed manually. The parameter only gets active on the PID after pressing the button To PLL.

element.label: I (Hz/deg/s)
element.desc: Integral gain I coefficient used for calculation of the response of the PID model. The parameter can be optimized with PID advise or changed manually. The parameter only gets active on the PID after pressing the button To PLL.

element.label: D (Hz/deg*s)
element.desc: Derivative gain D coefficient used for calculation of the response of the PID model. The parameter can be optimized with PID advise or changed manually. The parameter only gets active on the PID after pressing the button To PLL.

element.label: D Limit TC/BW 3 dB
element.desc: The cutoff of the low-pass filter for the D limitation, shown as either the filter time constant or the 3 dB cutoff frequency, depending on the selected TC mode. When set to 0, the low-pass filter is disabled.

element.label: Rate
element.desc: PID sampling rate used for simulation.
element.descExt: The advisor will update the rate to match with the specified target bandwidth. A sampling rate close to the target bandwidth and excessive higher bandwidth will results in a simulation mismatch.

element.label: BW (Hz)
element.desc: Simulated bandwidth of the full close loop model with the current PID settings. This value should be larger than the target bandwidth.

element.label: Target BW LED
element.desc: Green indicates that the target bandwidth can be achieved. For very high PID bandwidth the target bandwidth might be only achieved using marginal stable PID settings. In this case, try to lower the bandwidth or optimize the loop delays of the PID system.

element.label: PM (deg)
element.desc: Simulated phase margin of the PID with the current settings. The phase margin should be greater than 45 deg for internal PLL and 60 deg for all other DUT for stable conditions. An Infinite value is shown if no unity gain crossing is available to determine a phase margin.

element.label: Stable LED
element.desc: Green indicates that the phase margin is fulfilled and the PID system should be stable.

element.label: To PID
element.desc: Copy the PID Advisor settings to the PID.

element.label: DUT Model
element.desc: Type of model used for the external device to be controlled by the PID.
element.descExt: A detailed description of the transfer function for each model is found in the previous section.

option.label: All Pass
option.desc: The external device is modeled by an all pass filter. Parameters to be configured are delay and gain.

option.label: LP 1st
option.desc: The external device is modeled by a first-order low-pass filter. Parameters to be configured are delay, gain and filter bandwidth.

option.label: LP 2nd
option.desc: The external device is modeled by a second-order low-pass filter. Parameters to be configured are delay, gain, resonance frequency and damping ratio.

option.label: Resonator Frequency
option.desc: The external device is modeled by a resonator. Parameters to be configured are delay, center frequency and quality factor.

option.label: Internal PLL
option.desc: The DUT is the internal oscillator locked to an external signal through a phase-locked loop. The parameter to be configured is the delay.

option.label: VCO
option.desc: The external device is modeled by a voltage controlled oscillator. Parameters to be configured are delay, gain and bandwidth.

option.label: Resonator Amplitude
option.desc: The external device is modeled by a resonator. Parameters to be configured are delay, gain, center frequency and quality factor.

element.label: Delay
element.desc: Parameter that determines the earliest response for a step change. This parameter does not affect the shape of the DUT transfer function.

element.label: Gain
element.desc: Parameter that determines the gain of the DUT transfer function.

element.label: BW (Hz)
element.desc: Parameter that determines the bandwidth of the first-order low-pass filter respectively the bandwidth of the VCO.

element.label: Damping Ratio
element.desc: Parameter that determines the damping ratio of the second-order low-pass filter.

element.label: Center Frequency
element.desc: Parameter that determines the resonance frequency of the of the modeled resonator.

element.label: Q
element.desc: Parameter that determines the quality factor of the modeled resonator.

element.label: Enable
element.desc: Enable the modulation

element.label: Mode
element.desc: Select the modulation mode.

element.label: Mode
element.desc: Enabling of the first sideband and selection of the position of the sideband relative to the carrier frequency for manual mode.

option.label: Off
option.desc: First sideband is disabled. The sideband demodulator behaves like a normal demodulator.

option.label: C + M
option.desc: First sideband to the right of the carrier

option.label: C - M
option.desc: First sideband to the left of the carrier

element.label: Mode
element.desc: Enabling of the second sideband and selection of the position of the sideband relative to the carrier frequency for manual mode.

option.label: Off
option.desc: Second sideband is disabled. The sideband demodulator behaves like a normal demodulator.

option.label: C + M
option.desc: Second sideband to the right of the carrier

option.label: C - M
option.desc: Second sideband to the left of the carrier

element.label: Frequency (Hz)
element.desc: Sets the frequency of the carrier.

element.label: Frequency (Hz)
element.desc: Frequency offset to the carrier from the first sideband.

element.label: Frequency (Hz)
element.desc: Frequency offset to the carrier from the second sideband.

element.label: Carrier
element.desc: Select the oscillator for the carrier signal.

element.label: Sideband 1
element.desc: Select the oscillator for the first sideband.

element.label: Sideband 2
element.desc: Select the oscillator for the second sideband.

element.label: Harm
element.desc: Set harmonic of the carrier frequency. 1=Fundamental

element.label: Harm
element.desc: Set harmonic of the first sideband frequency. 1 = fundamental

element.label: Harm
element.desc: Set harmonic of the second sideband frequency. 1 = fundamental

element.label: Demod Freq (Hz)
element.desc: Carrier frequency used for the demodulation and signal generation on the carrier demodulator.

element.label: Demod Freq (Hz)
element.desc: Absolute frequency used for demodulation and signal generation on the first sideband demodulator.

element.label: Demod Freq (Hz)
element.desc: Absolute frequency used for demodulation and signal generation on the second sideband demodulator.

element.label: Channel
element.desc: Select Signal Input for the carrier demodulation

custom.label: Signal Input, Current Input, Ref / Trigger, Auxiliary Inputs, Auxiliary Outputs
Signal Inputs, Trigger Inputs, Auxiliary Inputs, Auxiliary Outputs, Phase Demod 4, Phase Demod 8
Signal Input 1, Signal Input 2

element.label: Channel
element.desc: Select Signal Input for the sideband demodulation

custom.label: Signal Input, Current Input, Ref / Trigger, Auxiliary Inputs, Auxiliary Outputs
Signal Inputs, Trigger Inputs, Auxiliary Inputs, Auxiliary Outputs, Phase Demod 4, Phase Demod 8
Signal Input 1, Signal Input 2

element.label: Phase
element.desc: Phase shift applied to the reference input of the carrier demodulator and also to the carrier signal on the Signal Outputs

element.label: Phase
element.desc: Phase shift applied to the reference input of the sideband demodulator and also to the sideband signal on the Signal Outputs

element.label: Zero
element.desc: Adjust the carrier demodulator phase automatically in order to read zero degrees.
element.descExt: Shifts the phase of the reference at the input of the carrier demodulator in order to achieve zero phase at the demodulator output. This action maximizes the X output, zeros the Y output, zeros the Θ output, and leaves the R output unchanged.

element.label: Zero
element.desc: Adjust the sideband demodulator phase automatically in order to read zero degrees.
element.descExt: Shifts the phase of the reference at the input of the sideband demodulator in order to achieve zero phase at the demodulator output. This action maximizes the X output, zeros the Y output, zeros the Θ output, and leaves the R output unchanged.

element.label: Order
element.desc: Filter order used for carrier demodulation

element.label: Order
element.desc: Filter order used for sideband demodulation

element.label: TC/BW Value
element.desc: Defines the low-pass filter characteristic in the unit defined above for the carrier demodulation

element.label: TC/BW Value
element.desc: Defines the low-pass filter characteristic in the unit defined above for the sideband demodulation

element.label: Signal Output
element.desc: Select Signal Output 1, 2 or none

element.label: Carrier (V)
element.desc: Set the carrier amplitude

element.label: Modulation (V)
element.desc: Set the amplitude of the first sideband component.

element.label: Modulation (V)
element.desc: Set the amplitude of the second sideband component.

element.label: Index
element.desc: In FM mode, set modulation index value. The modulation index equals peak deviation divided by modulation frequency.

element.label: Peak Dev (Hz)
element.desc: In FM mode, set peak deviation value.

element.label: Enable FM Peak Mode
element.desc: In FM mode, choose to work with either modulation index or peak deviation. The modulation index equals peak deviation divided by modulation frequency.

element.label: Enable
element.desc: Enable the signal generation for the first sideband

element.label: Enable
element.desc: Enable the signal generation for the second sideband

element.label: Enable
element.desc: Enable the carrier signal

element.label: Enable
element.desc: Enable the BOXCAR unit

element.label: Input Signal
element.desc: Select Signal Input used for the boxcar analysis.

element.label: Osc
element.desc: Selection of the oscillator used for the boxcar analysis

element.label: Frequency (Hz)
element.desc: Oscillator frequency used for the boxcar analysis.

element.label: Too high frequency
element.desc: Frequency for the boxcar is above or equal 450 MHz. Sticky flag cleared by restarting the boxcar. The boxcar output may not be reliable any more.

element.label: Copy from cursors
element.desc: Take cursor values to define Window Start and Window span values.

element.label: Show Gate Opening
element.desc: Show gate opening on the PWA plot.

element.label: Start Mode
element.desc: Selects the mode to specify the start of the boxcar averaging gate opening. The phase (deg) is the native mode for the device.

option.label: Start (deg)
option.desc: Native definition of the boxcar averaging gate start as phase.

option.label: Start (s)
option.desc: Definition of the boxcar averaging gate start as time. Due to the conversion to phase on the device a small uncertainty window exists.

element.label: Start (deg)
element.desc: Boxcar averaging gate opening start in degrees. It can be converted to time assuming 360 equals to a full period of the driving oscillator.

element.label: Start Time (s)
element.desc: Boxcar averaging gate opening start in seconds based on one oscillator frequency period equals 360 degrees. Boxcar must be disabled to edit input field.

element.label: Width Mode
element.desc: Selects the mode to specify the width of the boxcar averaging gate opening. The time (s) is the native mode for the device.

option.label: Width (deg)
option.desc: Definition of the averaging gate width as phase.

option.label: Width (s)
option.desc: Native definition of the averaging gate width as time.

option.label: Width (pts)
option.desc: Definition of the averaging gate width in samples.

element.label: Width (deg)
element.desc: Boxcar averaging gate opening width in degrees based on one oscillator frequency period equals 360 degrees. Boxcar must be disabled to edit input field.

element.label: Width (s)
element.desc: Boxcar averaging gate opening width in seconds. It can be converted to phase assuming 360 equals to a full period of the driving oscillator.

element.label: Width (pts)
element.desc: Boxcar averaging gate opening width in samples at 1.8 GHz rate.

element.label: Too large gate width
element.desc: Boxcar averaging gate opening width is more than one cycle of the signal and should be reduced.

element.label: Copy from cursor
element.desc: Take cursor value to define Baseline Start value.

element.label: Start Mode
element.desc: Selects the mode to specify the start of the boxcar baseline suppression gate opening. The phase (deg) is the native mode for the device.

option.label: Start (deg)
option.desc: Native definition of the boxcar baseline suppression gate start as phase.

option.label: Start (s)
option.desc: Definition of the boxcar baseline suppression gate start as time.

option.label: Offset (deg)
option.desc: Definition of the boxcar baseline suppression gate start relative to the gate opening start as phase.

option.label: Offset (s)
option.desc: Definition of the boxcar baseline suppression gate start relative to the gate opening start as time.

element.label: Start (deg)
element.desc: Boxcar baseline suppression gate opening start in degrees based on one oscillator frequency period equals 360 degrees.

element.label: Start (s)
element.desc: Boxcar baseline suppression gate opening start in seconds based on one oscillator frequency period equals 360 degrees.

element.label: Start (deg)
element.desc: Boxcar baseline suppression gate opening start in degrees relative to Gate Start.

element.label: Start (s)
element.desc: Boxcar baseline suppression gate opening start in seconds relative to Gate Start.

element.label: Enable
element.desc: Enable Baseline Suppression

element.label: Averaging Periods
element.desc: Number of periods to average. The output will be refreshed up to 512 times during the specified number of periods. This setting has no effect on Output PWAs.

element.label: Averaging BW
element.desc: The 3 dB signal bandwidth of the Boxcar Averager is determined by the oscillation frequency and the Number of Averaging Periods set. Note: internally the boxcar signal is sampled at a rate of 14 MSa/s and the signal bandwidth of the auxiliary output is 7 MHz.

element.label: Rate Limit (Sa/s)
element.desc: Rate Limit for Boxcar output data sent to PC. This value does not affect the Aux Output for which the effective rate is given by min(14 MSa/s , Frequency / max(1, Averaging Periods/512)).

element.label: Rate (Sa/s)
element.desc: Display of the currently effective rate used for data transfer to the PC given by min(14 MSa/s , Frequency / max(1, Averaging Periods/512)). This value is read-only.

element.label: Rate Limit (Sa/s) or Rate (Sa/s)
element.desc: Switches between display of Rate Limit or Rate

option.label: Rate Limit (Sa/s)
option.desc: Display of the Rate Limit which defines the maximal transfer rate.

option.label: Rate (Sa/s)
option.desc: Display of the currently active transfer rate.

element.label: Oversampling
element.desc: Indicates, in powers of 2, the number of averager outputs sent to the PC while Averaging Periods Boxcar integrations are obtained. Positive integer values indicate oversampling. Negative integer values indicate undersampling.
element.descExt: Examples for oversampling values: 0 : 2^0 = 1 averager output is sent to the PC during Averaging Periods Boxcar integrations. 2 : 2^2 = 4 averager outputs are sent to the PC during Averaging Periods Boxcar integrations. -1 : 2^-1 = 0.5, only every other Averaging Periods Boxcar integrations an averager output is sent to the PC.

element.label: Value
element.desc: The current boxcar output.

element.label: Value Overflow flag
element.desc: Overflow detected. Sticky flag cleared by restarting the boxcar. The boxcar output may not be reliable any more.

element.label: Sample Loss
element.desc: Data lost during streaming to PC. Sticky flag cleared by restarting the boxcar.

element.label: Run/Stop
element.desc: Continuously run and stop PWA acquisition.

element.label: Single
element.desc: Single acquisition of a PWA data set.

element.label: Input Signal
element.desc: Select PWA input signal.

custom.label: Signal Inputs, Trigger Inputs, Auxiliary Inputs, Auxiliary Outputs, Phase Demod 4, Phase Demod 8

element.label: Input Interlock
element.desc: Interlock PWA and Boxcar Input settings

element.label: Osc
element.desc: Select reference oscillator for PWA signal acquisition.

element.label: PWA Frequency
element.desc: Actual frequency at which the PWA operates based on set oscillator frequency and harmonic scaling factor.

element.label: Commensurability
element.desc: Traffic light showing whether the number of samples acquired is evenly distributed over all bins.

element.label: Run/Stop
element.desc: Continuously run and stop PWA acquisition.

element.label: Single
element.desc: Single acquisition of a PWA data set.

element.label: Input Signal
element.desc: Select PWA input signal.

element.label: Osc Select
element.desc: Select reference oscillator for PWA signal acquisition.

element.label: Frequency
element.desc: Actual frequency at which the PWA operates based on set oscillator frequency and harmonic scaling factor.

element.label: Commensurability
element.desc: Traffic light showing whether the number of samples acquired is evenly distributed over all bins.

element.label: Mode
element.desc: Measurement data can be interpreted in four different modes and displayed over either phase (native), time, frequency (FFT) or harmonics of the base frequency (FFT).

element.label: Copy from range
element.desc: Change PWA start and span according to plot range.

element.label: Reset
element.desc: Reset the start and width value to show the full 360 deg.

element.label: Start
element.desc: Defines the start of PWA range in time or phase.

element.label: Width
element.desc: Defines width of PWA range in time or phase.

element.label: Samples
element.desc: Defines the number of samples acquired of each PWA data set (450 MSa/s).

element.label: Acq Time (s)
element.desc: Estimated time needed for recording of the specified number of samples.

element.label: Overflow
element.desc: Indicates whether the number of samples collected per bin or the amplitude exceeds the numerical limit. Reduce number of samples and/or change frequency.

element.label: Infinite Acq Time
element.desc: The signal source of this unit (Boxcar) is not producing any data. Once it is configured and enabled, this field will indicate the duration of a single measurement.

element.label: Progress (%)
element.desc: Show state of the PWA acquisition in percent.

element.label: Resolution
element.desc: FFT resolution (bin width) in Hz.

element.label: Max Harmonics
element.desc: Maximum number of displayed harmonics.

element.label: Signal
element.desc: Select signal to be displayed.

element.label: Run / Stop
element.desc: Runs the AWG continuously.

element.label: Single
element.desc: Runs the AWG once.

element.label: Sampling Rate
element.desc: AWG sampling rate. This value is used by default and can be overridden in the Sequence program.

element.label: Amplitude (FS)
element.desc: Amplitude in units of full scale of the given AWG channel. The full scale corresponds to the Range voltage setting of the Signal Outputs.

element.label: Mode
element.desc: Select between direct mode and amplitude modulation mode.

option.label: Direct
option.desc: Output of AWG goes directly to Signal Output.

option.label: Modulation
option.desc: Output of AWG channel 1 (2) is multiplied with oscillator signal of demodulator 4 (8).

element.label: Status
element.desc: Display compiler errors and warnings.

element.label: Compile Status
element.desc: Sequence program compilation status. Grey: No compilation started yet. Green: Compilation successful. Yellow: Compiler warnings (see status field). Red: Compilation failed (see status field).

element.label: Register selector
element.desc: Select the number of the user register value to be edited.

element.label: Register
element.desc: Integer user register value. The sequencer has reading and writing access to the user register values during run time.

element.label: Input File
element.desc: External source code file to be compiled.

element.label: New
element.desc: Create a new sequence program.

element.label: Revert
element.desc: Undo the changes made to the current program and go back to the contents of the original file.

element.label: Save (Ctrl+S)
element.desc: Compile and save the current program displayed in the Sequence Editor. Overwrites the original file.

element.label: Save as... (Ctrl+Shift+S)
element.desc: Compile and save the current program displayed in the Sequence Editor under a new name.

element.label: Automatic upload
element.desc: If enabled, the sequence program is automatically uploaded to the device after clicking Save and if the compilation was successful.

element.label: To Device
element.desc: Sequence program will be compiled and, if the compilation was successful, uploaded to the device.

element.label: Sync Status
element.desc: Sequence program synchronization status. Grey: No program loaded on device. Green: Program in sync with device. Yellow: Sequence program in editor differs from the one running on the device.

element.label: Counter
element.desc: Current position in the list of sequence instructions during execution.

element.label: Status
element.desc: Displays the status of the sequencer on the instrument.

element.label: Sequence Editor
element.desc: Display and edit the sequence program.

element.label: Assembly
element.desc: Displays the current sequence program in compiled form. Every line corresponds to one hardware instruction and requires one clock cycle (4.44 ns) for execution.

element.label: Mem Usage (%)
element.desc: Size of the current sequence program relative to the device cache memory. The cache memory provides space for 1024 instructions. Mem Usage > 100% means that instructions must be loaded from the main memory during playback, which can lead to delays.

element.label: Waveforms
element.desc: Lists all waveforms used by the current sequence program.

element.label: Mem Usage (%)
element.desc: Amount of the used waveform data relative to the device cache memory. The cache memory provides space for 32 kSa of waveform data. Mem Usage > 100% means that waveforms must be loaded from the main memory (128 MSa per channel) during playback, which can lead to delays.

element.label: Level (V)
element.desc: Defines the analog trigger level.

element.label: Hysteresis Mode
element.desc: Selects the mode to define the hysteresis size. The relative mode will work best over the full input range as long as the analog input signal does not suffer from excessive noise.

option.label: Hysteresis (V)
option.desc: Selects absolute hysteresis.

option.label: Hysteresis (%)
option.desc: Selects a hysteresis relative to the adjusted full scale signal input range.

element.label: Hysteresis (V)
element.desc: Defines the voltage the source signal must deviate from the trigger level before the trigger is rearmed again. Set to 0 to turn it off. The sign is defined by the Edge setting.

element.label: Hysteresis (%)
element.desc: Hysteresis relative to the adjusted full scale signal input range. A hysteresis value larger than 100% is allowed.

element.label: Rise
element.desc: Trigger on the rising edge.

element.label: Fall
element.desc: Trigger on the falling edge.

element.label: Signal
element.desc: Selects the analog trigger source signal. Navigate through the tree view that appears and click on the required signal.

element.label: Force
element.desc: Enforce a trigger event.

element.label: Gating
element.desc: Select the signal source used for trigger gating if gating is enabled.

element.label: Gating enable
element.desc: If enabled the trigger will be gated by the trigger gating input signal.

element.label: Signal
element.desc: Selects the digital trigger source signal.

element.label: Enable
element.desc: Enable impedance calculation for demodulator data.

element.label: Mode
element.desc: Select impedance measurement mode.

option.label: 4 Terminal
option.desc: The 4 Terminal method uses the current and the voltage drop across the DUT to calculate the DUT impedance. This method results in very accurate measurements as influences of series resistors on the output and current input are excluded.

option.label: 2 Terminal
option.desc: The 2 Terminal method uses the driving voltage and the measured current to calculate the DUT impedance. The 2 Terminal method can be beneficial when measuring very high impedance where the parasitics of the voltage measurement are limiting the frequency range.

element.label: Representation
element.desc: Representation of the complex impedance value Z by two real values accessible as Parameter 1 and Parameter 2 on all user interface displays.

option.label: Rp || Cp
option.desc: Impedance value Z is represented by a resistive element Rp in parallel with a capacitive element Cp.

option.label: Rs + Cs
option.desc: Impedance value Z is represented by a resistive element Rs in series with a capacitive element Cs.

option.label: Rs + Ls
option.desc: Impedance value Z is represented by a resistive element Rs in series with a inductive element Ls.

option.label: G B
option.desc: Impedance value Z is represented by conductance G = Real(Y) and Susceptance B = Imag(Y) of the admittance Y = 1/Z.

option.label: D Cs
option.desc: Impedance value Z is represented by a dissipation factor D (loss tangent) and a capacitive element.

option.label: Q Cs
option.desc: Impedance value Z is represented by a quality factor Q = 1/D and a capacitive element.

option.label: D Ls
option.desc: Impedance value Z is represented by a dissipation factor D (loss tangent) and an inductive element.

option.label: Q Ls
option.desc: Impedance value Z is represented by a quality factor Q = 1/D and an inductive element.

element.label: Parameter 1
element.desc: Currently active representation parameter 1. A representation is based on the measured impedance and the frequency. Representations are only valid within a specific frequency or impedance region.

element.label: Parameter 2
element.desc: Currently active representation parameter 2. A representation is based on the measured impedance and the frequency. Representations are only valid within a specific frequency or impedance region.

element.label: Osc Frequency
element.desc: Frequency control for the oscillator used for impedance measurement.

element.label: Range Control
element.desc: Select input range control mode.

option.label: Manual
option.desc: In manual mode the current and voltage input ranges are adjusted manually and separately. Use this mode with care as overflow and underflow will result in inaccurate impedance results.

option.label: Auto
option.desc: Dynamically adjust the input range according to the measured input signal strength. This optimizes the dynamic range and precision of impedance measurements.

option.label: Impedance
option.desc: Impedance range is fixed. The current and voltage inputs are adjusted so that the selected impedance can be measured with the currently active excitation with best precision. Use this mode to avoid automatic range adjustments in a frequency sweep.

element.label: Suppressed
element.desc: Indicates disabled periodic auto range control. A running sweeper module takes over the range control and thus disables the periodic range checks.

element.label: Impedance Range
element.desc: Select a fixed impedance range used for the measurement.

element.label: Current Range
element.desc: Input current range used for the impedance measurement. Small current input range have a reduced bandwidth. In the Range Control modes "Auto" and "Impedance", the current range is switched automatically to a higher range if the frequency is too high.
element.descExt: The current input range is the overall current range given by the external amplifier and device input range.

custom.label: 100 nA, 1 µA, 10 µA, 100 µA, 1 mA, 10 mA
10 µA, 100 µA, 1 mA, 10 mA

element.label: Voltage Range
element.desc: Input voltage range used for the impedance measurement.
element.descExt: The internal impedance calibration is only performed for the voltage input ranges given in the list. If a different voltage input range is selected the closest calibration data will be used.

element.label: Drive Control
element.desc: If enabled, the drive voltage amplitude is controlled by the device. If disabled it can be set manually.

element.label: Amplitude
element.desc: Drive amplitude on the Signal Output.

element.label: Bandwidth Control
element.desc: Enable automatic bandwidth control. If enabled the optimum bandwidth is calculated based on the frequency and measurement data.

element.label: Max Bandwidth (Hz)
element.desc: Limit of the maximum bandwidth used on the demodulator filter. Values above 1 kHz can heavily diminish measurement accuracy in the high-frequency region where the amplitude is no more constant over frequency.

element.label: ω Suppression (dB)
element.desc: Suppression of the omega and 2-omega components. Small omega suppression can diminish measurements of very low or high impedance because the DC component can become dominant. Large omega suppression will have a significant impact on sweep time especially for low filter orders.

element.label: Suppression Ratio
element.desc: Error amplification limit for which a secondary parameter is marked unreliable. Larger gain values mean larger warning tolerances. A gain value between 10 and 100 is best.

element.label: Suppression Enable
element.desc: The Suppression Confidence Indicator indicates if one of the two parameters of a circuit representation cannot be calculated reliably from the measured impedance. This is the case if a small variation in one (dominant) representation parameter creates a strong variation of the other (suppressed) representation parameter. Such an error amplification indicates that the measurement of the secondary parameter is unreliable.

element.label: Compensation
element.desc: Strength of the compensation that will trigger the strong compensation warning.

element.label: Compensation Enable
element.desc: Enables the indication of strong compensation in the plots. A strong compensation diminishes the measurement accuracy of the parameter.

element.label: Open Detect
element.desc: Open terminal detection ratio. An open terminal is reported if the excitation calculated from current and voltage drop differs more than the specified factor from the driving voltage.

element.label: Open Detect Enable
element.desc: Enables the open terminal detection for 4-terminal measurements. If enabled, an open terminal is indicated in the numeric tab and in plots.

element.label: Underflow Detect
element.desc: The underflow condition is met if the measured amplitude is lower than the specified ratio relative to full scale.

element.label: Underflow Detect Enable
element.desc: Enables the underflow detection for current and voltage. If enabled, an underflow will be shown in the numeric tab and in plots.

element.label: Mode
element.desc: Switch between application-based or manually configured impedance settings. A parameter set given by an Application mode can be fine-tuned by changing to Advanced mode. Changing back to Application mode will reset the parameters.

option.label: Application
option.desc: The impedance settings are adjusted to fit best the selected application.

option.label: Advanced
option.desc: The impedance settings are manually configured.

element.label: Application
element.desc: Select the Impedance application

option.label: LCR Impedance Measurement
option.desc: General-purpose settings for measuring components at finite frequency

option.label: DC Impedance Measurement
option.desc: Settings for measuring resistance at zero frequency.

element.label: Bias Control (V)
element.desc: DC bias voltage applied across the device under test. Both positive and negative bias voltages are supported. In a 4-terminal measurement, the bias voltage is limited by the maximum common voltage input range of the device. In a 2-terminal measurement, the bias voltage can be larger because the voltage inputs are not connected.

element.label: Bias Control Enable
element.desc: Enables bias control. The bias is generated by the additional offset applied on the output.

element.label: Current Input
element.desc: Select the current input used for two- and four-terminal impedance measurements.
element.descExt: The HF2TA needs to be connected to this input in order to measure the current.

element.label: Current Invert Enable
element.desc: If enabled, the current input signal is inverted. This is useful to switch the polarity of an input signal which can be caused by additional current amplifiers.

element.label: Voltage Input
element.desc: Select the voltage input used for a four-terminal impedance measurement.

element.label: Voltage Invert Enable
element.desc: If enabled, the voltage input signal is inverted.

element.label: AC
element.desc: Defines the input coupling for the Signal Inputs. AC coupling inserts a high-pass filter.

element.label: Current Demodulator
element.desc: Demodulator used for current demodulation.

element.label: Voltage Demodulator
element.desc: Demodulator used for voltage measurement in case of a four-terminal impedance measurement.

element.label: Output Demodulator
element.desc: Demodulator unit used to generate the excitation voltage on the Signal Output.

element.label: Interpolation
element.desc: Select the interpolation method of the compensation data. The interpolation method is particularly important if the derivative changes strongly e.g at cut-off frequencies.

option.label: Linear
option.desc: The linear interpolation is fastest but may create compensation errors in between the frequency points used for compensation.

option.label: Piecewise Cubic Hermite (PCHIP)
option.desc: The piecewise cubic Hermite interpolation will result in very accurate results but requires more calculation power.

element.label: Osc
element.desc: Oscillator used to generate the frequency of the excitation voltage on the Hcur (+V) connector.

element.label: Harm
element.desc: Multiplies the demodulator's reference frequency with the integer factor defined by this field.

element.label: Order
element.desc: Select the filter roll-off between 6 dB/oct and 48 dB/oct. High filter orders are beneficial for impedance measurements as they help to suppress DC offsets.

option.desc: 1st order filter 6 dB/oct
2nd order filter 12 dB/oct
3rd order filter 18 dB/oct
4th order filter 24 dB/oct
5th order filter 30 dB/oct
6th order filter 36 dB/oct
7th order filter 42 dB/oct
8th order filter 48 dB/oct

element.label: TC/BW Select
element.desc: Define the display unit of the low-pass filters: time constant (TC), noise-equivalent power bandwidth (BW NEP), 3 dB bandwidth (BW 3 dB).

option.label: TC
option.desc: Define the low-pass filter characteristic using time constant of the filter.

option.label: BW NEP
option.desc: Define the low-pass filter characteristic using the noise-equivalent power bandwidth of the filter.

option.label: BW 3 dB
option.desc: Define the low-pass filter characteristic using the cut-off frequency of the filter.

element.label: TC/BW Value
element.desc: Defines the low-pass filter characteristic in the unit defined above.

element.label: Sinc
element.desc: Enables the sinc filter.

element.label: Rate
element.desc: Impedance data streaming rate. The same data rate is applied to the demodulators that are used for the impedance measurement.

element.label: On
element.desc: Main switch for the Signal Output corresponding to the blue LED indicator on the instrument front panel.

element.label: Range
element.desc: Defines the maximum output voltage that is generated by the corresponding Signal Output. This includes the potential multiple Signal Amplitudes and Offsets summed up. Select the smallest range possible to optimize signal quality.

option.label: 10 mV
option.desc: Selects output range ±10 mV.

option.label: 100 mV
option.desc: Selects output range ±100 mV.

option.label: 1 V
option.desc: Selects output range ±1 V.

option.label: 10 V
option.desc: Selects output range ±10 V.

option.label: 150 mV
option.desc: Selects output range ±150 mV.

option.label: 1.5 V
option.desc: Selects output range ±1.5 V.

element.label: Compensation Type Select
element.desc: Displays information on either internal calibration or user compensation.

option.label: Internal Calibration
option.desc: The internal calibration matches all voltage and current ranges over the frequency range in order to achieve a high dynamic impedance range.
option.descExt: The internal calibration is performed at Zurich instruments.
For a given combination HF2 device and HF2TA the internal calibration needs to be performed once by using the HF2ITF test fixture.

option.label: User Compensation
option.desc: The user compensation will correct for measurement setup influences like capacitive or inductive parasitics. It is applied on top of the internal calibration.

element.label: Internal
element.desc: Enables the internal calibration. This ensures that the input range gains match over the full frequency range. With enabled internal calibration the device fulfills the impedance accuracy specification. The internal calibration is a prerequisite to apply a user compensation.

element.label: Active
element.desc: Indicates if the internal calibration is applied to the measurement data.

element.label: Internal Calibration Info
element.desc: Display of meta data saved together with the internal impedance calibration data.

element.label: User
element.desc: Enables the compensation of the impedance data. The user compensation is correcting parasitics and delays caused by the external setup. The user compensation is applied on top of the internal impedance calibration.

element.label: Active
element.desc: Indicates that a valid compensation is active. If active the impedance data streams deliver amplitude and phase corrected data based on the impedance compensation.

element.label: User Compensation Info
element.desc: Display of meta data saved together with the user compensation.

element.label: Mode
element.desc: Select the user compensation sequence. If the sequence involves a short or open condition, it is essential to keep the noise small by using auto range on the voltage and current inputs.

option.label: None
option.desc: No compensation is performed.

option.label: SOL (Short-Open-Load)
option.desc: Compensation of user setup using a short-open-load condition. This compensation method results in very accurate results over the whole impedance range under the condition of low-noise open and short compensation. Thus, this compensation should always be used with enabled auto range.

option.label: OL (Open-Load)
option.desc: The open-load compensation is suited for measuring high impedance. Use auto range to reduce the influence of noise for the open compensation step.

option.label: SL (Short-Load)
option.desc: The short-load compensation is suited for measuring low impedance.

option.label: L (Load)
option.desc: Compensation performed with a single load. This compensation is useful if the measured DUT is close to the load used for compensation.

option.label: SO (Short-Open)
option.desc: The short-open compensation corrects for inductive and capacitive parasitics of the user setup. This compensation method is suited if no load is available for the compensation. It will not correct gain errors.

option.label: LLL (Load-Load-Load)
option.desc: The compensation based on three load values results in very accurate results for a restricted impedance range. Use this method if the noise on the open or short condition is too strong.

option.label: Internal Calibration
option.desc: The internal calibration method is important to achieve a good range matching. The internal calibration must be performed once for a specific HF2 and HFTA combination. A good input range matching is essential to perform later a user compensation using auto ranging.

element.label: Load R
element.desc: Resistance value of the compensation load.

element.label: Load C
element.desc: Capacitance value of the compensation load. In case of a resistor load the capacitance value is equivalent to its capacitive parasitics.

element.label: Step
element.desc: Compensation step to record. The sequence of the steps can be freely selected. Before starting the correct device needs to be connected to the setup.

element.label: Status
element.desc: Indicates a successful compensation step. If the status indicator does not indicate green after a compensation step, check the message box to learn more about the failure.

element.label: Compensate
element.desc: Start the compensation measurement for the selected condition. If a compensation measurement is completed successfully, the next pending condition is automatically selected. The message box will contain information on the quality of the completed compensation and failure messages in case of a fail. The progress of the currently active compensation run will be shown in the message box.

element.label: Message
element.desc: The message pane displays information related to compensation. In case of a failed compensation, information on the root cause is reported. In case of successful compensation, representative parameters are reported to judge the quality of the compensation and measurement setup.

element.label: Comment
element.desc: User comment that will be saved together with the compensation data. The comment string can also be changed between the different compensation steps.

element.label: Validation
element.desc: Perform a sanity check of the compensation result to detect outlier measurement results, overflow, or other error conditions. Validation should only be disabled for compensations performed in special conditions.

element.label: Auto Transfer
element.desc: If enabled, a successful compensation will be immediately transferred to the device, activated, and stored permanently. If automatic transfer is disabled, the transfer needs to be initiated manually.

element.label: On Device
element.desc: Transfer and activate the recorded compensation manually.

element.label: Persistent
element.desc: Store the compensation data persistently on the device. The compensation will be loaded automatically on every power-up.

element.label: Start (Hz)
element.desc: Lower frequency limit used for calibration. For measurements at lower frequencies than this value, an extrapolation is performed.

element.label: Stop (Hz)
element.desc: Upper frequency limit used for calibration. This upper limit is essential for correct measurements.

element.label: Points
element.desc: Number of frequency points used for compensation. For frequencies between two compensation frequencies the data will be interpolated.

element.label: Enable
element.desc: Enable the pulse counter unit.

element.label: Mode
element.desc: Select the run mode of the counter unit.

option.label: Free Running
option.desc: The counter runs on a repetitive time base defined by the Period field. At the beginning of each period the counter is reset, and at the end, the accumulated number of counts is output.

option.label: Gated Free Running
option.desc: The counter runs on a repetitive time base defined by the Period field. The Gate Input signal controls when the unit counter is allowed to run. The counter as well as the timer is reset when the Gate Input signal is low. The counter will only deliver new values if the Gate Input signal is high for a time longer than the configured Period.

option.label: Gated
option.desc: The counter is controlled with the Gate Input signal. The counter is enabled at the rising edge of the Gate Input signal and disabled at the falling edge. Pulses are counted as long as the counter is enabled. The accumulated number of counts is output on the falling edge of the Gate Input signal.

option.label: Time Tagging
option.desc: Every pulse is detected individually and tagged with the time of the event. The Period defines the minimum hold-off time between the tagging of two subsequent pulses. If more than one pulse occurs within the window defined by the Period, then the pulses are accumulated and output at the end of the window. The Period effectively determines the maximum rate at which pulse information can be transmitted to the host PC.

element.label: Period
element.desc: Set the period used for the Free Running and Gated Free Running modes. Also sets the hold-off time for the Time Tagging mode.

element.label: Input
element.desc: Select the counter signal source.

custom.label: Ref/Trigger Input 1/2, Trigger Input 3/4, DIO Bit 0-31

element.label: Gate Input
element.desc: Select the signal source used for enabling the counter in the Gated Free Running and Gated modes.

custom.label: Ref/Trigger Input 1/2, Trigger Input 3/4, AWG internal Trigger 1-4

element.label: Operation
element.desc: Select the arithmetic operation (addition, subtraction) applied to the counter unit outputs. "Other counter" refers to the grouping of the counter units: 1 with 2, and 3 with 4.

element.label: Integrate
element.desc: Sum up counter values over time.

element.label: Value
element.desc: Displays the counter output value.

element.label: Input Shield
element.desc: Select the shield of Input 1 and 2 to be either grounded or biased by an external voltage

element.label: Offset (V)
element.desc: Set the offset voltage applied to the current input.

element.label: R1 / R2 (V/A)
element.desc: Set the transimpedance gain of the amplifier

element.label: DC
element.desc: Switch between DC and AC coupling after the first amplification stage

element.label: G1 / G2
element.desc: Set the voltage gain of the second amplification stage

element.label: Aux Output
element.desc: Set the auxiliary output voltage of the HF2TA

element.label: Single
element.desc: Switch between differential and single-ended input configurations

element.label: R (Ω)
element.desc: Select input impedance

element.label: DC
element.desc: Switch between DC and AC coupling after the first amplification stage

element.label: G1 / G2
element.desc: Set the voltage gain of the second amplification stage

element.label: Help
element.desc: Show the online user manual.

element.label: Discovering
element.desc: Searching for devices.

element.label: Local / All Data Servers
element.desc: Change display of data server list between local only and all data servers.

element.label: Connect
element.desc: Connect to the selected device.

element.label: Change
element.desc: Change server connectivity to different host name and port number.

element.label: Host
element.desc: IP address of the connected LabOne Data Server. If empty, no data server is connected.

element.label: Device and UI
element.desc: Load both device and UI settings.

element.label: UI Only
element.desc: Load UI settings only.

element.label: Default
element.desc: Load the default UI settings.

element.label: Command log
element.desc: Shows the last command. A different formatting (Matlab, Python, ..) can be set in the config tab. The log is also saved in [User]\Documents\Zurich Instruments\LabOne\WebServer\Log

element.label: Show Log
element.desc: Show the command log history in a separate browser window.

element.label: Session
element.desc: Indicates the current session identifier.

element.label: Device
element.desc: Indicates the device serial number.

element.label: Next Calibration
element.desc: Remaining minutes until the first calibration is executed or a recalibration is requested. A time interval longer than 99 minutes is not displayed. Manual calibration mode is indicated by an "M".

element.label: CAL
element.desc: State of device self calibration. Yellow: device is warming up and will automatically execute a self calibration after 16 minutes. Grey: device is warmed-up and self calibrated. Red: it is recommended to manually execute a self calibration to assure operation according to specifications.

element.label: REC
element.desc: A green indicator shows ongoing data recording (related to global recording settings in the Config tab).

element.label: AWG
element.desc: Arbitrary Waveform Generator - Green: indicates that the AWG unit is enabled.

element.label: CNT
element.desc: Pulse Counter - Green: indicates which of the pulse counter modules is enabled.

element.label: IA
element.desc: Impedance Analyzer - Green: indicates which of the impedance analyzer modules is enabled.

element.label: AU
element.desc: Arithmetic Unit - Green: indicates which of the arithmetic units is enabled. Red: indicates owerflow.

element.label: CF
element.desc: Clock Failure - Red: present malfunction of the external 10 MHz reference oscillator. Yellow: indicates a malfunction occurred in the past.

element.label: OVI
element.desc: Signal Input Overflow - Red: present overflow condition on the signal input also shown by the red front panel LED. Yellow: indicates an overflow occurred in the past.

element.label: OVO
element.desc: Overflow Signal Output - Red: present overflow condition on the signal output. Yellow: indicates an overflow occurred in the past.

element.label: COM
element.desc: Warning flags related to instrument communication. From left to right: Packet Loss, Sample Loss. Packet Loss - Red: present loss of data between the device and the host PC. Yellow: indicates a loss occurred in the past. Sample Loss - Red: present loss of sample data between the device and the host PC. Yellow: indicates a loss occurred in the past. A possible cause for sample loss may be the scope running in parallel.

Warning flags related to instrument communication. From left to right: Packet Loss, Sample Loss, Stall. Packet Loss - Red: present loss of data between the device and the host PC. Yellow: indicates a loss occurred in the past. Sample Loss - Red: present loss of sample data between the device and the host PC. Yellow: indicates a loss occurred in the past. Stall - Red: indicates that the sample transfer rates have been reset to default values to prevent severe communication failure. This is typically caused by high sample transfer rates on a slow host computer.

element.label: C
element.desc: Reset status flags: Clear the current state of the status flags

element.label: RUB
element.desc: Rubidium Clock - Grey: no rubidium clock is installed. Yellow: Rubidium clock is warming up (takes approximately 300 s). Green: Rubidium clock is warmed up and locked.

element.label: BOX
element.desc: Boxcar - Green: indicates which of the boxcar units is enabled.

element.label: MOD
element.desc: MOD - Green: indicates which of the modulation kits is enabled.

element.label: PID
element.desc: PID - Green: indicates which of the PID units is enabled.

element.label: PLL
element.desc: PLL - Green: indicates which of the PLLs is enabled.

element.label: Full Screen
element.desc: Toggles the browser between full screen and normal mode.
